reviewText: I love rhythm games. Stepmania used to occupy all my time when I was younger, but this game is just so messy. Casting spells then waiting for them would create awful timing where you'd end up having to defend yourself by the time your spell appear, so you'd have to stagger your timing, and failing a spell will punish you with reallocating your timing between attacking and defending to regenerate your mana. To make it worst, each fight is a timelimit based on the song's length so if you get to a choppy start, you're pretty much screwed. Timing is everything with rhythm games and for me there's just too much to keep track for me to enjoy actually playing the game.\nPlus, this game is a pain in the ♥♥♥ if your play style involves two hands.

reviewText: Sequence is probably the first game ever that has combined a rhythm type game with RPG. Make no mistake this is an indie game, the rhythm feature is rather lackluster and the watered down RPG leaves a lot of be desired. The developers claim that this game should take you 12 hours, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It will take you 6 hours max to beat this game if you skipped item farming. Combine item farming with the rather limited collection of music and you are in for one hell of a repetitive ride. Luckily this game makes up for all of its errors with its impressive voice acting; the various bosses you meet have various distinct personalities that make them super memorable. The game presentation is also very beautiful and organized. The music, although limited, is ridiculously catchy. Finally the game base price is five dollars that alone negates every negative thing said about this game! Go buy it and promote creative indie development.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of Rhythm games and RPGs I thought that this game would be amazing, but I am extremely disappointed.

While I ultimately ended up playing on Spasmodic difficulty, and am capable of getting 100% on several songs when I 'practice' in the bonus mode, the RPG elements, coupled with the field switching mechanic makes many foes extremely challenging.

Speaking of RPG elements, there is absolutely no explanation of the actual mechanical effects of the offense and defense stats. It's logical to assume that defense decreases the damage you take from missed gems, which is in turn multiplied by the gem color, but no indication is given about how much defense reduces how much damage.
Coupled with the fact that you can't see actual concrete stats from enemies (only vague bars), and the RPG mechanics seem to be a gimick that was tacked on to a rhythm game to make it 'harder' without requiring them to add more songs or harder difficulties for the songs.

Ultimately, I'd rather play something like Stepmania on the harder difficulties for my Rhythm game fix, and then play an RPG like Dragon Age or one of the various Elder Scrolls.

I give this game a 2/5. I might have given it a 3/5 purely for the snarky dialogue during the cutscenes, but the audio quality is hit and miss. (You can tell that certain lines were recorded on different days when the ambient sound changes)

reviewText:
So I got this game for like 50 cents.  It's marked at 5$, so I'm going to treat it like it's a 5 dollar game.

It's not worth 5 dollars.  Want a decent 5 dollar game?  Check out Knights of Pen and Paper, or when you grow a sack get X-Com UFO Defense.

So why isn't this game good?  I've played tons of rhythm games and this one has 'decent' music, but has no real assemblence of something you could nod your head to and say: yea, this works in a rhythm game.  It simply doesn't and the input is bad.  Now to meet anyone that says: maybe you're just bad at rhythm games, maybe I am, but I the music alone is not motivating and doesn't telegraph much of a downbeat let alone figuring out the count.

The game tries extremely hard to be hip and ironic.  Using references of date ♥♥♥♥, crystal meth, and getting stabbed by a hobo in less than 1 minute to get you to say: YEA, THIS IS HIP!

It's a huge grindfest that just wares down compared to other grind games [like Knights of Pen and Paper].  You have to find items by selecting monsters to fight, then craft items from those items found, but you have to spend xp to increase the rate of success.  If you fail, everything you bid is lost and you have to go back to the half-hazardly made ACID-Pro electronic music.

It's 5 dollars, sure, but it's not at all worth that.

There's so much this game attempts to do that sounds really cool!  [That Bejeweled RPG game series that came out a few years back was actually cool!] This game is not!  It has a lot of things it's trying to do, but all of them are executed poorly.  If anyone can get through this rhythm game and say 'yea this music guides me', then you have an ear I simply do not possess.  The game even says, listen to the music not so much watch the arrows.  If you listen to the music, it will throw you off!  I muted this game and aced every monster I came across.

The music is 'good', but it's not good for rhythm based games.

reviewText:
Played this for a little more than 30 minutes and it's not what I expected. I expected an RPG with rhythm based combat, like it actually advertises. But it falls short on every level, except for the music. The music is actually something that I enjoyed listening to. The graphics are very basic; the art looks ok, but there are basically no animations. It feels very empty and simple. I'll admit I can't expect a 'retail quality' game for this price, it's true. But still, if you build expectations you better deliver.
The combat is a nice idea, but poorly executed. You pick an enemy from a list (I know, right?) and then fight it by pressing buttons on the beat of the music. It's nothing fancy, and about everything is text based, items included.
You explore the tower by picking levels from a list as well. Wait, what?
There's just no style; it doesn't stand out. There are some cool ideas in it, but like I said, it's really, really poorly executed.
Sorry guys, it's not worth the money.

[Rating: 69/100]

reviewText:
This game is regular rhythm game with small extra gimmicks but little content.

In this game, like in other rhythm games, you press different keys (in this case arrow keys) in the rhythm of music. The extra gimmick of this game is that you simultaneously fight against monster and there are different rhytm lines for Mana, Attack and Defence. See some videos about this, if you want to know more as I am not going to explain this further in this review.

This little gimmick is not bad, but it isn't revolutionary either. In the end the game is extremely bland and for a person like me who isn't fan of this kind of genre, the game was waste of time excluding funny conversations that the characters make in the story that gave some delight. What makes me not to recommend this game is that it is very repetitive. There is only a few of songs and the gimmick that this game has is seen very quickly.


Grade: 5/10

I would only recommend this to a person who is fan of this genre and who has tried all other variations of this kind of games.

Last edit was to change Grade from 4 to 5 to be more in line with my other reviews.

Impulse buy after seeing the screens and noting it was a rhythm game RPG. Equip gear and spells and pretty much play DDR across 3 panels. One is a mana panel which will replenish your mana pool for every correct note" you hit. One is a Defense panel where when your monster attacks notes will popup and for every miss you start loosing hp. In your attack panel notes will appear depending on what spell you cast. Some will deal damage some will heal you and others will cast buff/debuff on the playing fields. The difficulty will change appropriately at least for people who have played the konami music games. A little tricky getting used to panel swapping but all in all a pretty interesting and well done rhythm music game."
Tetris meets Rockband Plenty fun!

RPGs meet Dance Dance in this Hybrid action title, Featuring an excellent original story, fully voiced dialogue, and extremely fun, yet sometimes challenging gameplay. Also, you can kill Ghouls and Ghosts THROUGH THE POWER OF MUSIC!!!

I honestly grabbed this as an impulse by and its actually quite good. Its pretty difficult at first but it gets easier. The best way I can describe it is like a Battle - DDR RPG... Or Puzzle Quest with DDR instead of Bejeweled.
It costs just 0,99 € and it gave me 12 hours of fun. Casual funny simple but challenging. TRY IT !!\n
You cannot imaging my happiness at this game.  DDR + RPG.  Also, the story is dripping with irony and sarcasm.

The voiceacting and writing are painfully self-aware. Trying too hard to make fourth wall allusions. The rhythm part of the gameplay is challenging, but crafting seemed like an artificial barrier to more rhythm gameplay.
Awesome game, especially for such a low price. A lot of fun, challenging, and interesting. It takes a little bit to get the hang of, but once you do it's a major time waster.

Bit of a mixed bag, Sequence is a rhythm game about using three different playing to fight monsters.  There's the defense field in which you defend against incoming attacks by aggressors by blocking their attacks pressing the corresponding keys.  The spell field in which you cast spells with different effects such as DoT, healing, or fast recharge low damage spells.  And the mana field in which you replenish mana, which is used to cast spells, you can only have one of these fields open at a time and there is a time limit for defeating the monster, which is an interesting concept.  The monsters have a chance of dropping various items, the lower the more rare and they all give a different amount of experience. You use your experience to craft items, spell scrolls, or keys which you use to use to progress, herein lies some of the problems of the game.  It feels like a grind, just a huge grind.  You end up wasting so much time either killing the same monster over and over again to find that ONE item you need to make better gear or spells, and you can end up wasting all of that precious expereince you earned making you down on experience, although you do lose out on some items.  It just gets very very repetitive around floor four you notice none of the spells bring anything new to the table.  It doesn't help the writing isn't super compelling.  Not to mention the music is reused and the only time you feel like you're actually playing a rhythm game is when you're in the mana field, which is when the keys actually feel like they correspond to the music.  It's got cute ideas but it's riddled with flaws, it's worth checking out if you feel confident sinking money into just to get a feel for it, hey if you're into the grind and slamming on keys for 10 seconds at a time (roughly how long it takes to get your mana replensihed) then be my guest.

at first i just could not get the game at all as in attacking and deffending and the mana thing was a bit confusing. BUT after i got used to switching the pannels to attack and deffend and stuff it was not that hard. i could play this game all day too. gameplay is simple and stuff and cida easy to get used to. i also like the RPG feel to it too it's added a bit of fun to the game without it it would just be a DDR game and thats boring.\n\nso 10/10

I enjoyed this game, it was pretty unique. I only wish it were longer.

This game is good. Games like Guitar Hero and DDR never caught my interest, but I still enjoyed this game's gameplay quite a lot. I do, however, like RPGs (so long as they aren't basic, dry, turn based 1980s JRPG battles), and the gameplay here is quite at bit more engaging. Especially later on, you can get some battle strategy going.\n\nAnyway, the rest of the game is good too. The story is good, especially the ending, and the characters/writing, voice acting, the item descriptions (deserves its own mention), and etc. And of course the music. For a music-based game to work, the music has to be good, and it is great here. Check out Ronald Jenkees and DJ Plaeskool and listen to a bit of the music, and if you like what you hear, play this game.
Best of rhythm and RPG gameplay, with cool songs and artwork.  It's definitely worth buying :)

TL;DR: Pure Awesome.

Sequence is a game that most people would ignore. At first glance, its just a Guitar Hero inspired simple shovelware game, right? WRONG. Sequence is a GREAT game, and I will tell you why.

- The music is fantastic, comming from YouTube legend Ronald Jenkees.
- The switching between screens and casting of spells makes for a great improvement of the otherwise single-minded GH style games.
- The story is also not to be underestimated. It's more engaging and introspective than most games you will have played.
- There is a lot of humour to be found in the game; almost every item name and description is a joke.
- Even the credits are engaging and fun to sit through. Great game design from the start of the game until the very end.
- A level of difficulty for everyone, with a good curve.

If you are still not convinced, just watch the trailer and see the greatness of the game and the person behind it.
You cannot imaging my happiness at this game.  DDR + RPG.  Also, the story is dripping with irony and sarcasm.

Very unique spin on an otherwise commonly used rhythm game mechanic.

Anyone who has played rhythm games is all too familiar with the standard mechanic of having 4 columns of arrows falling in tune with the music. Sequence manages to make a very strong tactical/multi-tasking game out of it by having 3 seperate grids. One grid is the mana grid, which you use to get mana to cast spells - it's very common to miss lots of beats here in preference to landing beats on the other 2 grids. This is also where the beats primarily follow the song. Another grid is the defensive grid - beats that fall here and you don't hit will reduce your HP until you hit 0 and lose. The other grid is the spell grid. At any time you have the mana for it, you can choose to cast a spell - the effects vary from dealing damage to the enemy, healing, lifestealing, hitting the enemy with damage over time, giving yourself a mana boost, boosting the strength of the next spell you cast. Each individual spell has its own beat combination that doesn't change with the exception of inverting a few presses, left instead of right, etc, and also significant changes between difficulties. All these different spells are balanced by difficulty of input, how much blank space is there in between beats (to allow for swapping to other grids), as well as cooldown before you can cast that same spell again. Anything less than 100% on a spell input results in it failing, going on cooldown, and using up mana.

All those different factors result in a very frantic level of multi-tasking that I have never seen in this genre, and continuously leaves me mentally engaged, instead of just sitting back and hitting buttons corresponding to a beatmap all day. Incredibly satisfied with Sequence for gameplay originality and engagement.

Music: I'm not that big of an electronica fan, however, Ronald Jenkees has made a good effort to change my mind on that. The music for the beatmaps are all catchy. DJplaeskool did a good job with the rest of the soundtrack.

Writing/dialogue: There is a large community wide disagreement between enjoyment and annoyance of the dialogue between the 2 main characters, so your mileage will vary heavily in that regard. What I can say from an objective point of view is that it is very mechanically solid, all the characters in the game have lots of personality, and the voice acting also performs just as well as the writing.

Story: The story is neat and fairly original, and with an excellent great reveal at the end.

RPG Elements: Probably my least favorite aspect of the game, but they work solidly enough. In order to progress to a higher level in the tower, you need to do the same 3 beatmaps on the existing level enough times to collect enough drops to craft a key to be able to start the boss fight to go to the next level. This part is just fine, since it encourages a not-excessive amount of replaying the same content to a good amount of replayability. By collecting those drops, you can also craft items that make it so your spells are stronger, you have more survivability, and/or a larger mana pool. There's also experience that gets used to improve those stats via level ups, and gets used in crafting. The big reason why I'm iffy on this, is that especially on the higher difficulties, I put myself in a dilemma of whether I just need to get less bad at the game, or if I just need to grind out some better stats to give me a better fighting chance.

Overall: All the parts come to work together without any major flaws to spoil the image, and where the game truly excels is its innovative take with the 3-grid system.

One of the best - and one of a kind.

Think Guitar Hero, but with an entertaining RPG backstory, geeky in-jokes everywhere, excellent voice acting, stunning artwork AND an excellent new take on the rhythm game mechanic - which requires you to watch and change between 3 separate streams of notes" while only being able to hit one stream at a time....

...so really not all that much like Guitar Hero - much better!"

Personally used a DS4 gamepad for Sequence. Having played through it using only the gamepad, I have no idea how it handles with a keyboard, but I can say that the gamepad felt completely natural to use. Switching through the fields using the triggers was outright cathartic.

Sequence is a gameplay-focused game, and the gameplay is as fantastic as it is interesting. The field-based rhythm combat isn't just a novelty, it has handfuls of legitimate merit. I'd even go so far as to call it innovative. The inherent multi-tasking and battle system means that the game is less execution-heavy than you might like, but playing on Hard did mean that Piano Jam left my fingers aching nonetheless.

Battle system itself revolves around the use of skills and micromanaging several fields. Things start to fall apart here - the usefulness of skills is determined by your stats (automatically allocated after each level-up) entirely and utterly. Pulling off a skill doesn't nearly matter as much as the stats behind it, and at several points in the game I had to go to a previous area to grind up a few levels because I was simply unable to deal enough damage to defeat an enemy in the time allocated (you only have until the song ends). Taking into account that the insurmountable enemies in question were rather easy otherwise, it was a total chore.

Stats don't belong in this game - instead of skillfully outmaneuvering the enemy through sick beats, you're either painfully chipping away at their health pool or utterly annihilating them, and all in the space of about 2-3 levels.

The reason this game has so many stats is because it also bills itself as an RPG, and stats are a required part of that I guess. It fails as one. There's no sense of playing a role whatsoever, and the worldbuilding is so thin it completely collapses under itself at several points. All the item descriptions are all completely irrelevant puns (funny ones, but quick wit doesn't flesh out a world), and the entire premise is waved off by the characters as intentionally arbitrary, which tries as hard to engage as a prince betrothed to a simian. This game is about as much an RPG as your average dating sim.

You progress through the game through the game's shallow crafting system. Choose an enemy to fight, and they have a chance to drop an item. Use these items to craft an item that will allow you to progress to the next area. How quickly you are able to craft this item depends on whether or not an enemy decides to drop the item. While it should be noted that there are some late-game items that increase item drop rate, the progression remains steadfastly a nightmare. Farming for items isn't fun. Whoever thought it was fun is a monster.

Combine this with that crafting recipes requires EXP. On it's own, this is a fantastic idea. However, combined with the stat-dependent gameplay and already tedious farm-based progression, it does nothing but serve to remind yourself how much of a chore it should have been to get through the game, had it not had the lucky break of being legitimately enjoyable to play. I don't see myself replaying it anytime soon, though.

The character banter is alright, though the story is so horrendous that I was left shocked by the sheer contrived garage leaking out of that final 10 minute exposition dump that sold itself as an ending. Shocked at a point I'd long since become apathetic. It's almost impressive how bad the plot is. The weak sense of intrigue initially spiked is just dragged out and finally shot like a dying dog. The super secret Sequel hook is hilariously nothing as well.

Art direction, I found, was fine, outside of rather cheap-looking UI. There's not enough of it though - there's a total of about 8 area images, and a single sprite per character or monster. No CGs for major events, and even those scarce few images are reused to hell and back. There's budget, and then there's ridiculous.

In spite of these problems, I completely and totally recommend that you play Sequence. The choice of music is stellar, the mechanics responsive, and as a whole the game is plain fun. The gameplay doesn't just carry it, it vaults it to the finish line. I'd love to see a sequel.

Regardless of its other issues (they're important to know, and I've spent the majority of the review ragging on them as a result), they're superficial to the very meaty game itself. And that's the bottom line.

Sequence does what Puzzle Quest did for block-clearing puzzlers but for the music/DDR-eque games. The gameplay is very addicting and the music is varied and fun to listen to while playing.  With such a low price, there is really no reason to miss out if you like rhythm games.

reviewText: This game is amazing. If a game that combines rhythm game and RPG appeals to you then this game would be something to look at even if that combination of genre wasn't so rare.\n\nFirst off to all the people who aren't scared off from thinking of potential problems or weirdness already, it's not just let's smash these genres together". It's very functional as a rhythm game and they made that part of gameplay the "battle" portion of the RPG. You switch between "fields" to either defend against attacks
date: cast spells or regain mana. The balance of strength of attacks and difficulty pulling them off feels nice and natural and the game overall feels just wonderfully made. Like any RPG you might need to grind a little but just remember to pay attention to getting good equipment and good spell usage and it shouldn't get too bad. I think the only negative I can really think about gameplay is there isn't any "turn based" alternative for anyone that isn't physically capable of playing a timing based game
recommended: but for the rest of it it's good to go.\n\nMusic and visual aesthetics might depend a bit on individual taste to say for sure but I personally loved both in this game.  The story is awesome too

Taking a simple DDR based rthym game and turning into an RPG combat system was a suprisingly good idea. Unfortunately the way progression in the game is very grindy, but the core combat mechanics are more than fun enough to keep you playing.
And while a simple arcade concept such as this could have easily gone with a cheesy and overly simplistic story, they went all out here, the game's got a very good story and is well voice acted.

Simply put, for the cheap price it's currently available at (or even better, free with There came an echoe) it'll provide hours of fun and a great story. Can't recommend it enough, Iridium studios are quickly becoming a studio to watch out for.

reviewText:
Games like Sequence are the reason Kickstarter and the Indie Game movement exist. It's not a perfect game, not everyone is going to enjoy it and it will never receive a lot of fame and recognition. However, for the niche audience that can appreciate it, Sequence is a game like no other.

The closest thing I can relate Sequence to is Puzzle Quest. The game doesn't play like Puzzle Quest but what that game did for Match-3 games, Sequence does for the rhythm genre. The base game has you traveling up a tower by fighting enemies, collecting their dropped items, and synthesising items such as keys, weapons and armor. Battles give you experience which will level up your stats while armor and weapons are equipable and can also improve your abilities.

Where Sequence differs from the average dungeon crawler is that combat is played out by putting you in a rhythm system similar to StepMania, if you're using a keyboard, but with three separate boards. One board is defensive, one board is for building mana and one is for casting spells. On the first board, any notes that you miss will count as damage against you so catching them defends your HP. The second board will have a constant stream of notes. Missing them doesn't hurt you but catching them restores your mana which you need to cast spells. The last board stays dormant until you cast spells, the only way to damage your opponents. When you cast a spell, it takes mana and makes you complete a short rhythm sequence. Failing it causes the spell to fail but completing it will cast that spell. While it can be a lot to juggle at once, the game does a great job of teaching you and ramping up the difficulty slowly in order to build your skills both in game and out.

The gameplay by itself is fun for a while but as the entire game is built around grinding items and EXP, it would get boring very quickly if it weren't for the well written story pushing players forward. The tone reminded me of The World Ends With You in the best possible way, but felt wholy unique. Your main character finds himself waking up in a tower with no idea how he got there. The voice of a girl named Naia tells you that you are stuck in this tower/game and you will need to make your way up 7 floors to escape so off you go. While there are some predictable moments, the story as a whole never becomes too transparent and despite a few moments when I swore I was done after one more battle, curiosity kept me pushing ever forward. The characters are all voiced as well and while none are particularly mind-blowing, it's a nice touch and the quality stayed consistent throughout. If you do find your bar set particularly high in regards to VO quality, they do have an option to turn it off as well although I doubt this will be necessary for most people.

That's not to say the game isn't without it's rough spots. For a music-based game, Sequence has a surprisingly limited soundtrack of only about 10 songs that show up in battle. This means several monsters will have you playing the same songs repeatedly. Thankfully, they aren't bad and some of them I didn't mind repeating but considering each monster all but requires multiple playthroughs anyway, don't be surprised if you wind up hearing the same song 10+ times. As that suggests too, the gameplay is simply too grindy and while item drops are pretty common, it can be irritating when you need one specific item and have to fight the same monster over and over just to move forward. Finally, the song balance is a bit odd as by the end of the game, the length of the song decided more battles for me than my HP did. It felt like very artificial difficulty (you lose if the song ends before killing the enemy) and it would have been nicer to have some of the songs be just a bit longer, especially in Floor 7. Depending on your strategy, you may not have a problem with this but it showed up several times in my game.

Overall, if you're looking for something different and enjoy music gameplay, Sequence is worth a shot.

reviewText: A hidden gem in the rhythm game genre, Sequence combines DDR and RPG style battles to form a game completely addicting and worth coming back to. The story draws you in, and the artstyle of this game certainly helps in keeping things look fresh and interesting. There's also some better good humor between the characters which at parts can be silly, but not really be enough to make you feel like none of the characters cares about whats going on. However, the game suffers from some problems such as a rather small song catalog and the occasional grind, but it isn't enough to ruin the entire experience. Another thing to note is that this game is designed for controllers, while you can play with a keyboard, and I haven't had many problems doing so. If you're into this kind of stuff, buy this game as soon as you can, it's a one of a kind experience.

Sequence lives at the intersection of rhythm and decision making.  The combat is harsh but enjoyabile while the ways in which you craft your abilities and purchase items harkens to picking attacks in an RPG.  Finding the right mix can make you unstoppable but only if you execute those attacks in the rhythm challenge as well.\n\nThe major complaint is the speed at which the songs get stale.  This game could've had tons of replayability had I not gotten sick of the songs halfway through the game.  It's possible to push through that failure for the story, but it's a major low point of this title (despite the small selection being rather good).
This game is amazing. Unique mashup and very fun and addicting. Good levels of difficulty and well made.\nRecommend like woah.

reviewText: A fun little rhythm game with an excellent sense of humour. Loved it the first time I played it and months later I picked it up to replay and giggled all over again at the cutscenes.

really good

An extremely novel idea executed very well. The story is so-so, and the voice acting feels like it was done by bored devs, but the gameplay and audio really make this a win. It is a mixture of a rythm game and an RPG, which pits you against an oppenent to music where you must hit notes on your gamepad/keyboard in rythm on one of 3 boards to win. 1 board gains mana, 1 casts various spells, and 1 defends on attack. Balancing which spells you take into fights, which boards you focus on, and handling the special abilities that bosses throw at you is a lot of fun. It doesn't hurt that the musical selection is also very good.

Interesting concept with the 3 different screens of arrows you have to switch through.  Tries very hard to be an 'offbeat RPG' like Puzzle Quest, but ultimately the RPG elements are unimportant and the story sequences feature a bunch of flat and emotionless voice actors trying to be hip and witty.

If fanboys of the Matrix got together and tried to film another Matrix with no budget and an all-new script they wrote themselves, the dialogue would probably sound like it does in this game.  It's painful.  If you watch the trailer and listen to one of the devs trying way too hard to be hip while describing the game, you'll understand why it turned out this way.

Sadly the music is a low point as well.  You would think in a game built entirely on timing, music and rhythm that the audio tracks would be a high point, but all of these tracks feel like recycled DDR tunes.

If at some point in your life you *really* enjoyed finger DDR or Stepmania, you might like this game.  Otherwise, skip it.
Epic Combo for Music-Rhythm and RPG!\nIncredibly addictive and awesome writing and voice acting!\n10/10!

In addition, the game has a unique brand of satirical, self-aware humor that pokes at sacred-cow RPG traditions and Internet jokes alike. Since it combines the RPG and rhythm genres, it can get very repetitive, but if you cn keep yourself interested, it makes for a great time, especially considering the low price. Thumbs up!

I really have to amend my previous recommendation.   This game is good, but it's not as great as I thought it would be.  The lack of RPG elements beyond combat and item use really kind of hobbles the game. This would be great if it fell back heavily on the rhythm game aspect of the game, because that genuinely shines.  The problem is, there are only a very small handful of songs.  Very small.   Each area, you don't get random encounters, you get a small stable of enemies to CHOOSE from.  Combat gets you items to combine into the key that gets you to the next area.  You will fight these same enemies over and over until you get the drops you want, playing through the same light airy techno/electronic music over and over.  The artwork is beautiful, if amateurish (it looks like it's hand painted by someone's really artistic friend), and the dialogue is fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic, and delivered very sarcastically and deadpan.  But this doesn't stop the actual gameplay from getting really tedious.

This game is excellent. Normally, RPGs and music games both face issues, but I can't readily see them in this title. It took the gameplay of Rockband: Unplugged for the PSP and made it actually functional, and into an intuitive battle system. The RPG elements, with the ability to gain and lose levels as you spend time bettering your character, made character building interesting and every upgrade felt impactful. The voice acting was well done too, though similarly with There Came an Echo the character development was not endearing, focused too much on antagonistic dialouge rather than meaningful trait building. Still, however, you can skip these scenes so you can get away from that as much as possible.

The game itself, I'll warn, has little replay value. There's no software to add custom tracks like in Audiosurf, the music gets used on multiple levels and, given you are grinding, you get to hear the songs over and over again. If the music was bad, this would have been worse of an issue but I can't honestly say that the songs were terrible and didn't go so far as to play abrasive music from Dubstep, etc. Other things I'd change would be additions of things like local PvP, clearer labeling on the spell circle to tell which spell was which and what numbers corresponded to which slice of the circle, and more than seven levels/three battle senarios per level.

All in all it is a fun game. For 5$, it has about as much content as you'd expect and with as polished as it looks, sounds, and feels I can't recommend it enough.

Cons:

· Lack of proper character animation: sometimes the game just feels plain. If only the artwork guys had made some basic animations for at least the characters, the game would look amazing and dynamic, specially in battles.

Nevertheless, it's a must play

reviewText:
As a long-time rhythm game (in this case Stepmania) player, I was really excited for Sequence. The game looked to be just the right mix between rhythm and RPG elements, with a fun soundtrack to back it up. Unfortunately the game gets a little too grindy for my taste - you can beat pretty much any encounter in the game provided that you're a high enough level.

Leveling up is a chore though, and the bonus for beating an enemy skillfully isn't enough to outweigh the immense grind. A lot of the depth of the game involved simple grinding to get better levels, as later bosses had too much health and an item or a couple of levels was enough to make it easy. The grinding is really boring though as the regular creatures usually don't pose much threat.

If you're a fan of rhythm games I'd recommend picking it up, but if you're new maybe give it a pass or play it on a lower difficulty. I played it on Hard because it said for the not musically challenged
date: but most of the difficulty came from luck not going in my favor.

At first I was skeptical of the quality of this game. I initially bought it because i got a 50% discount coupon from completing the Transistor card set bvut it turned outto be quite enjoyable. It's one of those DDR style music games where you have to hit the incoming directional arrows that time with the music. Yes, this is a rpg-ish game and you're probably wondering what music would have to do with that. Well, guess what? That's right, you dance battle the monsters and bosses. You play as some guy with no real fashion sense who gets to dance battle monsters or die trying. This game also features a storyline with quality voice acting and funny dialogue, A sassy companion in the form of a disembodied female voice, and one very sexy man-boss. Definitely recommend.

You're able to calibrate to your monitor/speaker settings so you'll have an accurate game no matter what system you have.  It doesn't require a demanding computer, either.\n\nEasy mode is fairly easy while the harder levels provide plenty of challenge for experts.   Ronald Jenkees' music is very catchy. reviewText: Take DDR, RPG elements, Great storyline and a sweet techno/electronic soundtrack and you have Before the Echo. Originally titled 'Sequence' (changed due to C&D I think?) this game is amazing. The art? Breathtaking. The music? Absolutely unique and charming. The play style? One of a kind. If you enjoy any derivitive of DDR or FFR, please try this game out!

The RPG where grinding is fun!If you are a fan of RPGs and rhythm games I highly recommend Before the Echo.

I've completed the first of seven levels and my impressions so far are positive.  The first thing the player is treated to is the banter between the protaganist and his unseen guide.  The voice acting is good and the dialogue is consistently amusing with the occasional chuckle-worthy highlight.

At each level the player is encouraged to create objects from recipes but the raw materials for each recipe are only acquired by defeating enemies.  The basic enemies drop one, two, or three different materials based on individual percentages so a specific drop is never guaranteed.  This requires the grind for which RPGs are famous.  The objects created from these recipes aren't required to progress in the game but because battles are resolved in fun rhythm challenges ala Dance Dance Revolution, why not obtain the materials to create the objects and try them out?

I was pleasantly surprised that the first boss I encountered was an Internet meme and my interest is only piqued to see what subsequent levels will bring.

You know you.  If resolving RPG combat by playing a rhythm game doesn't sound like fun to you, then take a pass on Before the Echo.  Otherwise, take a chance on it and you will likely be glad you did.
So great! Sequence is like to rhythm games as to what Puzzle Quest was to bejeweled.

Nice little music game.  Simple yet entertaining narative, and the game play can get intense at times.  There is also little easter eggs hidden in this game that give it that bit of a jump ahead from games that kind of just keep you on a linear path.\n\nFor such a low budget they did a great job with the game, and the music is really nice.

If you love rhythm games, specifically DDR, then look no further. Taking rhythm to the next level, you are forced to pay attention to up to three separate flows of arrows at the same time..and all while keeping beat. Utilizing the Dance Dance Revolution style of rhythm game, these arrows shall be used for offense, defense, and recovery as you battle your way through foe after foe.

What can make it particularly exciting is that no two battles are alike: by using your spells at different times, you essentially 'remix' the steps within the song yourself, providing a somewhat-new spin time and again.

Of course, with a rhythm game, you want its soundtrack to shine, and Before the Echo does not disappoint. With a variety of techno-like beats providing you with sweet ear-candy, you'll find yourself swaying or bobbing to the beat as you work to defeat your foes.

We've had Puzzle/Bejweled meets RPG in titles such as Puzzle Quest, and now the rhythm genre seeks to remix..and so far, it's shining.

There are a couple of very good reasons to play Sequence. Firstly, the gameplay is spot on. Like most rhythm games you are simply required to hit buttons in time to the music, but Sequence has some interesting mechanics. You have three lanes of incoming notes that you can switch between at any time. One of them is defensive; any notes you miss here deplete your health. In another lane you must time your button presses to increase your mana, which is used for spellcasting. The third lane is for the spells themselves. Once you cast a spell you need to hit a short sequence of notes in this lane for the spell to actually take effect.

This leads to quite a frenetic experience where you're constantly shifting between offense and defense. It can be frustrating and it takes some getting used to, but once you get the hang of it, it's pure gaming bliss that rivals the old classic Amplitude, not to mention Guitar Hero.

The other, and possibly more significant, reason to play this game is the music. Much of the music is provided by Ronald Jenkees, a man of prodigious melodic talent. I've played Sequence for a good few hours, but I've spent much, much more time listening to the music of Jenkees. It's truly phenomenal, and even if you have no interest in this game I'd recommend checking it out.

Sequence is not perfect. There are RPG elements, and while they work well enough I can't help thinking that so, so much more could have been done with them. I'm put in mind of Puzzle Quest, another game which combined RPG elements with a totally different style of game, but did it in a much more dynamic way. Perhaps the makers of Sequence didn't have the time or resources to go that far, but I do believe they could have come up with something a little more compelling that repetitive grind they've got in this game. Maybe for the sequel?

Nothing about this game could really make me not recommend it. Upbeat, yet oddly fitting battle music. It's art style was clearly done with great care and interest, and the story builds up to the point that once I had done everything, left me completely satisfied with my purchase.

Sequence is a game I strongly enjoyed playing not because of its music, art-style, or its plot, all of which are really well done. It's the unique gameplay that Sequence carries.

Yes, on first glance, it's like Dance Dance Revolution. However it's unique because you play three different windows that you can switch to at any time. One window is for defense, one is for regaining MP, and the other is for spells you cast. I kind of feel like a music mixer by switching between these three windows constantly and hitting several notes.

The thing that also makes Sequence shine is the fact that it has so much potential in its core game that it's one of those few games out there that could spawn a successful sequel if it wanted to! It's also a quick game (took me 7-8 hours to 100% the game on normal difficulty, maybe another hour or two to get the rest of the achievements) with lots of replayability in the other difficulty levels. It's only $5 too!
Fantastic game! More than 30+ hours of very entertaining gameplay, excellent music, an engaging storyline, and an overall great experience! Can't wait for a sequel!

Impulse buy after seeing the screens and noting it was a rhythm game RPG. Equip gear and spells and pretty much play DDR across 3 panels. One is a Defense panel where when your monster attacks notes will popup and for every miss you start loosing hp. In your attack panel notes will appear depending on what spell you cast. Some will deal damage some will heal you and others will cast buff/debuff on the playing fields. The difficulty will change appropriately at least for people who have played the konami music games. A little tricky getting used to panel swapping but all in all a pretty interesting and well done rhythm music game."

This game is a splice of a RPG and a rhythm based game. The gameplay itself is innovative and addictive. However there are two major problems that i personally have. Firstly its a massive grind, in order to get all the items you will have to battle each monster around three times if your lucky. This is about as fun as watching paint dry. Secondly the same songs are repeated a huge amount of times, when this is combined with the first point the game begins to grate on your nerves.\nI give this game a positive review though because i enjoy it immensely but it is not without its flaws.
Strangely addictive...once u get the hang of it.
The best argument for arrow keys.
This game is the awesome by all means. Awesome graphics, gameplay, music and story :DDDD, totally recommended. A great game for a low price :D
Pretty unique genre-blending (rhythm game RPG) with cheeky humor.

So far it's an awesome game! This game is a pleasent surprise, one of my favorite games I bought during winter sale (though even at full price it would be a good buy).

It's fresh and funny. The concept of a rhythm game mixt with RPG is well executed. The voice acting is great and I Iove the light and humorious dialogues. The more I discover about this game the more I want to keep playing.

Even if it's a great game, I wouldn't recommend it to people who have difficulties with rhythm (didn't look through all the difficulty levels though). As an exemple, it isn't a game for my brother... but he does enjoy watching me play it. Also, some might find it a bit repetitive, I could understand why but so is every RPG or RPG-like game.

Personnaly, it doesn't bother me, and it offers an ok variety of good music and intersting small adds to the gameplay along the way to not mind the little repetetiveness. This game has also a great pick up and play feel to it. Sometimes I just don't know what to play, my mouse is far away from me and I look for a game simple (yet more elaborated than a phone game) and enjoyable while browsing my library and Sequence fast became one of those games that I would just pick up, quickly remember where I left off and get back in right away.

If you're ok/good with rhythm and looking for something different then you should absolutly buy it! Keywords: Fresh and Funny ;)
If you like music and cards buy this game.

It's an RPG-Rythm game. You have 3 rhythm games at once (arrows dropping down and you need to match them with button presses), one for offense, defense and mana regeneration and you need to multitask between them.

Between the battles you can choose what kind of attacks you use (some are harder to activate but deal more dmg).

I enjoyed it a lot.

Brilliant little rhythm indie game, can take a while to get used to the controls, but once you do, you'll find yourself getting easily sucked in.\nThis mixed with some unique twists on RPG elements makes for a truly enjoyable experience, and for such a low price, it's hard to say no.
This game is insanely fun. It can get a little bit repetitive at times, but also really easy to just  chill and zone out" in. The music
recommended: are both really great. For the price
hoursPlayed: it's a must buy."

reviewText: Honestly, the game isn't...that great. The humour isn't that good, and whenever the girl speaks, I hear mic static, which made me laugh pretty hard. If you like stepmania you might like it, but the design is certaintly nothing amazing.
this is ♥♥♥♥ing hard to play couldn't even get passed the tutorial. took me like 10 goes over 2 days to get a pass. guess i just suck at DDR i mean Sequence.

Sequence is a fun game for any rhythm gaming fans. It is not very complex graphics or story-wise but has some fun mechanics. If you are looking for a great music RPG this is probably not going to be your kind of game but if you enjoy basic rhythm games then go for it. The music is fantastic and the voice acting is pretty good.
Come for the unique and creative mix of rhythm and RPG gameplay, but stay for the presentation, sequence is hands down one of the best deals on steam.
Seriously, play that game. For the price, it's a steal.
Fun game but the big turndown for me was the music, didn't like it that much. but it's a decent game

Great for anyone who likes rhythm games and provides a great challenge. It requires you to switch between 3 different fields constantly to defend yourself from oncoming attacks, pull off different spells to damage your opponents, and regain mana. Definitely a must play for anyone who enjoys a rhythm game with a twist!
Amazing game. Great music, Great humor.
This game has all the fixings from witty banter to pop-culture references right alongside an amazingly smooth gameplay experience.
a nice hidden gem
It's a cross between DDR and RPG.  It's a DDRPG.

You like rhythm games? And RPG elements, too? You want to feast your eyes on colourful character and background designs? And you don’t mind sometimes silly humour? You better not wait to hit that buy button!

‘Sequence’ gives you all this: wonderful music, colourful 2D graphics, silly but loveable dialogue and humour [apart from that Hitler joke maybe], and at its rhythm core a superb game where you’ll learn what it means to multitask.

The RPG element can become a chore at times [keyword: grinding] and a gamepad is very highliest recommended, but that shouldn’t keep you from playing a game that has so much character in the most positive sense of the word.
This is surprisingly good! I wouldn't have thought it works that well with a gamepad, but it does! Loads of fun, and great music, too.
A great, funny and very different game. The rhythm-game/classic-RPG mash-up works really well even though it does feature quite a bit of grinding. Playing it with a controller is advised

Phenomenal rhythm game. Really, the most enjoyable I've ever played besides DDR. It suffers from....bizarre dialogue and plot, occasionally funny, sometimes offensive in odd ways, but the design of the game is truly great. If you like rhythm games this is an absolute must.

It's a compulsively playable rhythm game made by Jonathan Blow wannabes. So the actual game part is pretty good, but between rounds you have to sit through ten minute long talking head cutscenes featuring irritatingly precious Diablo Cody style dialogue.
A must-play for anyone who calls themself a fan of rhythm games. Great value for the price.
AMAZING game, very original, good humour, deep plot, fun gameplay. Worth the price

Way more fun than I ever expected it to be. I am not a huge fan of rhythm games. But I installed Sequence for the 2011 Winter Sale achievement and the next thing I knew 2 hours of my life had vanished. The gameplay is incredibly fun and surprisingly engaging, the music is great (even if you typically don't like this genre or music, as I don't), and the dialogue is genuinely really funny.
An interesting premise - a rhythm game combined with an RPG - but it ends up being really grindy. Which is strange. And annoying.
Best rhythm game I've ever played. RPG elements, great music, amazing story! Buy it , it's super cheap !!!

Awesome indie game. It's a mix of RPG with stepmania/DDR/ITG. If you're good at any of these rhythm games, don't let the screenshots and videos fool you into thinking this is too easy. The challenge in this game comes from having to multi task all 3 different aspects of battle (gathering mana, defending, casting spells) and your ability to balance and decide which one to focus on. Its mechanics are also fairly simple and easy to get into.\n\nEDIT:  I just found out this game was patched to fix a bug where the hardest difficulty would randomly get changed to the easiest mode.  Now that I'm actually playing on the hardest difficulty, the charts are kinda hard by themselves but the battles are outright brutal now.
Fun and challenging game. Great music and a really intriguing story to acompany it. Lots and lots of geek/pop-culture references too. Definitely worth the 5usd!

Sequence is a rhythm based, story driven RPG that follows the story of Ky and his 'handler' Maya as they traverse a tower full of strange creatures, 'guardians,' and internet memes. It's a rather fun experience with great writing and a catchy soundtrack, although it can drag at times as you try to obtain the correct items for a portion / spell. Definitely worth a buy!

Better then you'd imagine for such a small indie game.  Love the combination of genres, finallyu something innovative and new for the music/dance games.  Excellent soundtrack, especially Outer Space" & "Guitar Sound" by Ronald Jenkees.  Check em out!"
fun rhythm game with rpg elements and awesome music
with a controller the gameplay gets addicting after a while.

A fantastic game in which all of the mechanics have been honed to perfection. The DDR Max-RPG hybrid system works flawlessly, the voice acting is top notch, and the dialogue is great. Little touches such as being able to spend experience points to increase synthesis success, having a practice mode to work on your timing, and more are all done well. The hand painted enviornments look gorgeous, and the character and enemy designs are great, although a couple of the later enemies are palette swaps of the early ones. The soundtrack is great, with several catchy songs you'll find yourself humming in the shower later. Unfortunately, the number of tracks is rather limited, and each enemy is assigned only one song, but the songs are still good enough that they don't get annoying. The only flaw I can find is that there is no free play mode, as at this point I have reached such a high level that even the hardest battles only take around thirty seconds to win. Still, its hard to fault a game for not letting you replay it enough, so I'll conclude by saying that this is the single best indie title I have had the pleasure of playing on Steam. A fantastic game that should be enjoyed by all.
Awesome and interesting!

This game took me totally by suprise. I bought it for 99p in a sale one time not expecting much - but holy cow, it's one of the most unique games I've played. In a cross between an RPG and keyboard version of DDR, you're a guy who's in a tower of killer monsters with no explanation as to why. The bosses have unique personalities and playing styles which means that as you advance the game never gets too boring. The only problem I might have with the game is it's lack of variety in the music department, but it's only a minor quibble for such a cheap game. Buy it now! It's that good!
A neat music game with a focus on plot... weird I know. The writing is awful but the story ain't bad and the game itself + music is really great. Bought it for $1.99
(~'V')~ Seriously the music, game, story, style all blew me away~ One of my all time favorite games!

A seeming simple game that combines music, RPG elements and humerous writing.  The player has to fight monsters on their way to the top of a mysterious tower.  The rhythm based gameplay come into effect in casting spells, defending against attacks, regaining mana and learning new spells.
Awesome game, it's like an RPG where you battle with a Flash Flash (Dance Dance) Revolution style thing. Super duper unique, really nice songs too! Get this if you like music games!
puzzle quest + rythm game = awesome\n
I would give this game a gold star, but honestly it's beyond gold stars.
DDR style Rythim game with RPG elements and a suprisingly good story.  I really enjoy it.

This game is a splice of a RPG and a rhythm based game. The gameplay itself is innovative and addictive. However there are two major problems that i personally have. Firstly its a massive grind, in order to get all the items you will have to battle each monster around three times if your lucky. This is about as fun as watching paint dry. Secondly the same songs are repeated a huge amount of times, when this is combined with the first point the game begins to grate on your nerves.\nI give this game a positive review though because i enjoy it immensely but it is not without its flaws.

Gameplay wise it is just hit the correct arrow at the correct moment, nothing new or exciting but the setting makes it worth while. The music is surprisingly good but it is the sense of humour and voice acting throughout the game that make it one of those games that peope end up playing by chance but are so glad they stumbled upon it. I got it free for supporting another game from the developer on kickstarter but I think this one was the real prize.
Dance Dance RPG!
A hidden gem among the sea of available games on Steam. The best things about it are, its brilliant humor, and the original mix of elements in the gameplay.
A surprisingly fun hybrid of rythym games and RPGs. Likeable characters, good sense of humor, and some kickass tunes.

Puzzle Quest is to Bejeweled as Sequence is to DDR. Sequence is a dungeon crawler / RPG of sorts in which battles are done in DDR-like matches. Of course, arrows are hit with keys instead of a dancepad. The twist is that there are three different playing fields, and you have to switch between them. One regains mana as you hit notes, one blocks incoming damage when you hit the notes, and one is for casting spells. It's an interesting concept, and while it's done very well, it still seems to be amateurish. I'm glad I played it for a bit to get a good idea of the game, but it's not worth the grinding to continue.
excellent music based game with rpg elements. Story is good too. Worth it

As someone who loved stepmania and was addicted to it for a long time this game feels right at home. It includes an interesting mechanic of swapping between windows to attack, defend or regenerate mana which at first takes some getting used to but after that it is like second nature.

The game includes some great soundtracks, and it was sad defeating an enemy early just because the song would end early. The audio goes perfectly with the visual aesthetics of the game  and the artwork is truly stunning.

There is some farming involved in progressing through the game but if you play any RPG this is nothing out of the ordinary.

Over all it is unique and lots of fun. great music and highly addictive.

A friend of mine actually recommended this game for me quite awhile ago, but i've only looked at a basic gameplay video, and that was it.\nMany months later, when i recieved my new notebook, and when Steam started doing huge sales, i decided to include games i was kinda" interested on to my wishlist
date: including this game. Then when this game hit 2 euros
recommended: i bought it.\n\nNow i'm gonna be honest here. From the boredom gameplay i'm getting from Stepmania
hoursPlayed: and similar DDR games with no intensity whatsoever
voteText: and from there are so many indie games i am "meh" at
helpfulPercent: i expected this game to be no diffirent.\n\nTurns out i was wrong on many levels. This game surpasses basic expection i thought this will be. Every ingame music i've heard so far are very catchy
votesHelpful: the voice acting is spot on and flawlessly perfect
votesTotal: the many internet references (possibly including a pony one aswell) are hilarious
commentsCount: and most importantly the gameplay is fantastic. Give this a try

reviewText: For $4.99, this is one of the most interesting games you can play.\n\nRhythm based rpg combat with quirky humour and an interesting cast of characters - who can say no to a game where the description of Polish Remover is Hitler"?"

Rather unqiue rythem game, if you've ever played stepmaina using a keyboard you should recongize the combat system a bit.  You basically get three feilds, one to rebuild mana, one to block attacks from your oppenent, and finally the last feild is for attacking with spells, all of which is timed to the tempo of the song.  Each spell uses a different sequence of steps as well. Each level you are collecting ingredents to make a key to continue on, or other items to help you in your quest. The caracthers are fully voiced, and are very charming and humorous.  At the price of some starbucks coffee or some meal you can't really go wrong.

Dear friends. Stepmania, the RPG. Some of you are already sold. GOOD.

Also included: witty writing and some pretty cool music you probably haven't heard before! Solid and interesting combat system, item system that is involved but not too overbearing (Have you played a JRPG / any RPG and successfully navigated crafting ever? Then you are certainly qualified) and really, really good art. Oh, and everything is voiced. EVERYTHING. And it is great.

Oh, and when I was talking about witty writing? Every single item has a description. Most of those descriptions will make you laugh, or at least do that I can't laugh in public but this is hilarious stop staring at me" thing. You know the one I mean."
This is a fantastic game... it mashes rhythm and rpg elements together and does it very well.

This is a DDR RPG. Yeah, odd. It pulls it off pretty well, actually, though DDR games live or die on the quality of their music. The music has a bit of variety, but it's mainly electro-techno-kind-of-stuff. A couple of piano tracks if I recall correctly, but you'll be spending a fair bit of time grinding XP on the same songs, which isn't great, but it doesn't really outstay its welcome. Original and fun, all up.
Like rhythm games and RPG's? Well then you'll love this game. The two types are thrown together very well in this game.

This game is simply amazing. If the idea of stepmania/DDR-like gameplay blended with rpg elements and a good story sounds good to you, get this game now. You can easily get a good 10 hours of gameplay here and even more :)
This game is really fun, one of the only games I've completed 100%. I didn't expect much, but the combat is really satisfying if you like rhythm games.

If I had heard someone say they were going to make an RPG that used Dance Dance Revolution as a combat system, I would have checked to make sure someone hadn't switched out my coffee for decaf, because there's no way something like that could actually happen.  And yet, this game exists.\n\nI'm not going to lie, there is a bit of a learning curve at first, but once you adjust to the (surprisingly smooth) concept of managing three different DDR boards at once, all in different fashions and priorities, the game really flows well.  The story is interesting, and the descriptions and names of the items you get really show how much the developers enjoyed making the game.  Speaking of the devs, they read the credits at the end, which plays out as more of a DVD commentary than a bland credit list.  This was actually the first time I've really cared about a credit sequence for anything, ever, so props to them for that.
Well worth it for the soundtrack alone, never mind the humor and unique take on the DDR formula.

Mix DDR and classic dungeon grinding RPGs and you get something that might resemble Sequence.  It's an excellent game with a really creative core and solid execution.  Full voice acting really helps to make the game feel more fully developed then the JRPG style 2D pictures would otherwise make you feel.

Music is excellent and really well made, however grinding for levels and items does mean you'll hear the same songs over and over again.  In the end, I think it was a valiant effort but I can definitely see how some people would tire from the inevitable grinding necessary to progress.

If you do give it a try, make sure you have a controller (or preferably a dance mat,) as the game is clearly designed with a controller in mind.

Overall probably worth the price, but definitely not for everyone.
This game is highly addicting with an incredibly amusing storyline. It's like a DDR RPG game for your fingers! I would reccomend it to anyone and everyone.
Game worth buying. Great gameplay, pretty good visulas and awesome soundrack.
this is ♥♥♥♥ing hard to play couldn't even get passed the tutorial. took me like 10 goes over 2 days to get a pass. guess i just suck at DDR i mean Sequence.

Sequence is a fun game for any rhythm gaming fans. It is not very complex graphics or story-wise but has some fun mechanics. If you are looking for a great music RPG this is probably not going to be your kind of game but if you enjoy basic rhythm games then go for it. The music is fantastic and the voice acting is pretty good.
Come for the unique and creative mix of rhythm and RPG gameplay, but stay for the presentation, sequence is hands down one of the best deals on steam.
A very interesting blend of RPG and Rhythm game mechanics. The comedy, quirkiness and overall flow of the game really has its own unique charm. I recommend it for lovers of either genre.

If you like rhythm games, this game is for you. You may satisfied playing Stepmania or Guitar Hero or what have you, but this is the real deal. It'll fill the void in your heart you didn't know you had.\n\nSomeone took a very good RPG, ripped out the battles and replaced with a dancing game and novel mechanics. This is a game within a game, and the developers nailed both of them. The visual novel style is not my type, and the game could have better replay value, but those flaws are compensated by the great story and solid gameplay.
Nice music!
Highly recomend it if you like rhythm games. It's pretty challenging and has a quirky, yet interesting story

RPG game design is blended incredibly well with rhythm gameplay to make a game unlike any other on the market. Would definitely recommend to anyone interested in RPGs who wants something a little different.

This game is good but REAAAAAAALLY needs more songs. If the idea of grinding the same song way too much isn't a game breaker this is a fun game with some neat ideas that don't quite work.  Super weak recommendation but its cheap so whatever, if it sounds fun to you, get it. This would be really good if they made another game of similar length but without the padding.
Rhythm RPG, very well done and funny
Nice combination of RPG and rhythm/music game. The story so far is awesome and the music quite good. But sadly, you can't use your own music. I can still recommend it!
A very interesting blend of RPG and Rhythm game mechanics. The comedy, quirkiness and overall flow of the game really has its own unique charm. I recommend it for lovers of either genre.

Surprisingly excellent. The game is witty and well written, and you'll enjoy it if you were addicted to games like stepmania.
Awesome

If I had to describe Sequence in one word it would be this: Fun. But I'm not going describing it in one word. I'm going to describe it in as many words as I can--and--hopefully in the clearest way possible. As the trailers will tell you Sequence is a lot like a DDR game. It has a great mix of rhythm and rpg elements laced within 4.99 (and as I write this review, 1.99) dollars of pure fun. The games mechanics sound difficult at first but once you get a grasp of them it really is just like a dance stepping game (dance stepping...yeah). You have three different fields, Magic, Defense, and Mana that you must use to defend yourself against a selection of creative monsters and even more creative (or perhaps creative-er...if that were a word) bosses in order to solve four things: Where are you? Who took you to said where? Who is this chick talking to you over an intercom system? Why the heck is there an intercom system in what looks to be a tower straight from a fantasy game?
The games plot: You are a young man named Ky, a university student who was brought to some unknown world where each wrong move could essentially be your last. But not to worry though! A very slick talking female voice is there to help you through your adventure through conveluted tower. With her aid you'll hopefully beat all fo the bosses and get to the 7th floor of the tower and...well...that's all the game tells you.
One thing I will tell you though is if you are looking for closure this isn't the game for that. The ending to this game isn't bad--no I found it highly satisfying. But it felt very cliff hanger...y for a game that as of right now is just a one shot. I assume this is so it can have some kind of sequel. Something I personally have my fingers crossed for. The music is wonderful, I'd never heard of Ronald Jenkins before this game and let me tell you I'm glad I did. Go ahead and look up his music to get a taste of what you'll hear in-game.
As with any grinding rpg you may find yourself feeling a bit bored from the repetitive fights, forging of materials through recipies and other little minute chores you have to do in the game. But I personally believe the music is what helps bring it together. Nothing ever really FEELS like a chore in this game. The monsters are relatively balanced, after you defeat and gather what you need for a boss you will feel like top dog for a few brief moments before getting brought back down a peg or two from the next monster one floor up. The only complaint I have is that the particle effect is too much for my computer and has a tendency to lag and affect your rhythm. This could just be my computer though. The dialogue is very well versed and thought out. Smooth gameplay mechanics and you rarely feel any mistakes made is anything but your own.
And the item descriptions. Oh the item descriptions.
Needless to say, I have a bit of a bias for this game and I want anyone reading this to take that in terms with this review. This is a very niche kind of game. If you love DDR games you'll love this to death I'm sure. But I do recommend checking it out for its low price alone.

I'm so happy i bought this game in a humble bundle. It's one of the best, if not the best, rythm games I have ever played. the use of both rythmic and RPG elements is perfectly done. The hidden humor in the item description made me laugh a few times. The vocals were superb and the artstyle was magnificent. I would seriously suggest this game.

I've never particularly been big on rhythm games, but this one is really unique. It's got some really great dialogue and voice acting, an intriguing story and a very simple and easy to use method of play. There's also a brilliant prize for those of you who stick it out till the very end - plus a good share of secrets and hiddens. Definitely recommended.
A-M-A-Z-I-N-G

Brilliant little rhythm indie game, can take a while to get used to the controls, but once you do, you'll find yourself getting easily sucked in.\nThis mixed with some unique twists on RPG elements makes for a truly enjoyable experience, and for such a low price, it's hard to say no.

When I first stumbled across Sequence, I was poking through games I had coupons for. I was a little hesitant at first to pay even the 90% off price because the trailer on the store page made the game sound rather complicated, and I wasn't sure how the gameplay would hold up.

However, I wound up caving and figured I'd buy it for the heck of it, and I'm really glad I did. Sequence is an excellent, solid game if you can play through everything. The soundtrack is wonderful, the game's artwork is spectacular, and the writing is witty and interesting which makes for a fun playthrough.

I've been actively trying to get my friends into playing because I wanted to share how wonderful this game really is. I'm commonly asked what it's like, which I'd have to say is really similar to Dance Dance Revolution, but played with the keyboard's arrow keys. It's definitely easier once you know the songs and beats, because you have to match hitting the falling arrows in time with the music, essentially.

Overall, I can't recommend this game enough. Sequence is a very excellent game.
/tcag
A great game that mixes in some fine tunes with some fine gameplay.

This game is a super fun rhythm game full of neat tunes and attractive artwork. The cast of irritatingly smug hipsters is tolerable and the gameplay is fresh as hell and a fun challenge for anyone familiar with Stepmania or similar fare.\n\nHighly recommended for anyone who isn't a noob, or adventurous types who are.
Awesome game! Combination of Guitar Hero -eqsue button pressing, spell casting and a great soundtrack. Great fun, I play far too much.
This is an awesome rhythm action/rpg hybrid.  Totally worth $5, or you can wait for it to go on sale.

This game was that summer fling that you could never forget. I don't know why I bought it and when it was over a piece of me went with it.
Truely one of the few inde games you will apreciate.

Sure I like some fun rythm games every now and then and maybe some games that will challenge me to be a better player, but what keeps me hooked until the end is that storyline. I'm all about the feels and this game's storyline delivers it.

STORY: 10/10
Everything about this game feels like a budget game, but the voice acting and the music and thought put into the story developement drove it home for me. I truely felt like I was experiencing all of the hard work each person put into this game I even took a moment of pause and watched the credits. its that good.

GAMEPLAY: 8/10
Lets be honest, rythm games are very hard to be creative with. You can only do so much to make a person appriciate the music and stay with the beat before it becomes too difficult or too generic.  They did a great job with attempting to give you more than just a beat to hit some buttons with, they gave you enemies to hammer down and spell combos to add a twist to the mix of some pretty good beats.

At first, juggling through 3 different rythm windows in a battle along with a timer taunting you to the very nano second to hammer out the best moves orElseUlolFail@life can be intimidating, but it actually makes a ton of sense and you feel like youre really battling it out with some baddies while head bobbing to the beat. For what they had to work with, this is something to really try out for yourself.

ART: 8/10
This isnt some blockbuster game that had millions of dollars backing it along with teams of graphic designers, so dont expect amazing CG movie like animations here ladies. The art for each stage is very unique and even melds with the music and the tone of the story. The characters do seem budget like, but by no means are they generic.

REPLAY: 5/10
Sometimes the replay has to justify the price, and this game definately had the opportunity to get some DLCs going of side quests, a battle arena for other players, hell even an after the tower storyline. I really did enjoy the game for what its worth, but after playing the entire thing including the extras in the first run I wished there was something more to comeback to later on.


Conclusion: I know you will pass buy this game as your browsing through the store looking for a quick fix and overlook it. I honestly dont recall what made me buy it in the first place, but I am glad I did and I am pretty sure you will be too. If youre that strapped, its just 5 bucks and you get a lot more bang for your buck from this game than you would for whatever 5 bucks can get you nowadays. Pick up this game and enjoy the adventure.

A bizarre, but highly addictive combination of game styles. The dialogue is oddly engaging, and left me wondering what would happen next. Reasonaby priced to boot. Definitely recommended for fans of rhythm games and titles with level-up systems.
Awesome Game. $5. That is all I have to say.
I got this game sole for Ronald Jenkees keyboarding genius. Turns out this whole game is genius. Get this game for a fun experience

Awesome game! Combination of Guitar Hero -eqsue button pressing, spell casting and a great soundtrack. Great fun, I play far too much.
This is an awesome rhythm action/rpg hybrid.  Totally worth $5, or you can wait for it to go on sale.

This game was that summer fling that you could never forget. I don't know why I bought it and when it was over a piece of me went with it.
Truely one of the few inde games you will apreciate.

Sure I like some fun rythm games every now and then and maybe some games that will challenge me to be a better player, but what keeps me hooked until the end is that storyline. I'm all about the feels and this game's storyline delivers it.

STORY: 10/10
Everything about this game feels like a budget game, but the voice acting and the music and thought put into the story developement drove it home for me. I truely felt like I was experiencing all of the hard work each person put into this game I even took a moment of pause and watched the credits. its that good.

GAMEPLAY: 8/10
Lets be honest, rythm games are very hard to be creative with. You can only do so much to make a person appriciate the music and stay with the beat before it becomes too difficult or too generic.  They did a great job with attempting to give you more than just a beat to hit some buttons with, they gave you enemies to hammer down and spell combos to add a twist to the mix of some pretty good beats.

At first, juggling through 3 different rythm windows in a battle along with a timer taunting you to the very nano second to hammer out the best moves orElseUlolFail@life can be intimidating, but it actually makes a ton of sense and you feel like youre really battling it out with some baddies while head bobbing to the beat. For what they had to work with, this is something to really try out for yourself.

ART: 8/10
This isnt some blockbuster game that had millions of dollars backing it along with teams of graphic designers, so dont expect amazing CG movie like animations here ladies. The art for each stage is very unique and even melds with the music and the tone of the story. The characters do seem budget like, but by no means are they generic.

REPLAY: 5/10
Sometimes the replay has to justify the price, and this game definately had the opportunity to get some DLCs going of side quests, a battle arena for other players, hell even an after the tower storyline. I really did enjoy the game for what its worth, but after playing the entire thing including the extras in the first run I wished there was something more to comeback to later on.


Conclusion: I know you will pass buy this game as your browsing through the store looking for a quick fix and overlook it. I honestly dont recall what made me buy it in the first place, but I am glad I did and I am pretty sure you will be too. If youre that strapped, its just 5 bucks and you get a lot more bang for your buck from this game than you would for whatever 5 bucks can get you nowadays. Pick up this game and enjoy the adventure.

A bizarre, but highly addictive combination of game styles. The dialogue is oddly engaging, and left me wondering what would happen next. Reasonaby priced to boot. Definitely recommended for fans of rhythm games and titles with level-up systems.
Awesome Game. $5. That is all I have to say.
I got this game sole for Ronald Jenkees keyboarding genius. Turns out this whole game is genius. Get this game for a fun experience

This game took me totally by suprise. I bought it for 99p in a sale one time not expecting much - but holy cow, it's one of the most unique games I've played. In a cross between an RPG and keyboard version of DDR, you're a guy who's in a tower of killer monsters with no explanation as to why. The bosses have unique personalities and playing styles which means that as you advance the game never gets too boring. The only problem I might have with the game is it's lack of variety in the music department, but it's only a minor quibble for such a cheap game. Buy it now! It's that good!
