puzzle quest + rythm game = awesome\n
I would give this game a gold star, but honestly it's beyond gold stars.
I dislike rhythm games. I dislike it when they try to encroach upon other genres. But this independently made Music RPG is astounding.
Strangely addictive...once u get the hang of it.
The best argument for arrow keys.
This game is the awesome by all means. Awesome graphics, gameplay, music and story :DDDD, totally recommended. A great game for a low price :D
Pretty unique genre-blending (rhythm game RPG) with cheeky humor.

So far it's an awesome game! This game is a pleasent surprise, one of my favorite games I bought during winter sale (though even at full price it would be a good buy).

It's fresh and funny. The concept of a rhythm game mixt with RPG is well executed. The voice acting is great and I Iove the light and humorious dialogues. The more I discover about this game the more I want to keep playing.

Even if it's a great game, I wouldn't recommend it to people who have difficulties with rhythm (didn't look through all the difficulty levels though). As an exemple, it isn't a game for my brother... but he does enjoy watching me play it. Also, some might find it a bit repetitive, I could understand why but so is every RPG or RPG-like game.

Personnaly, it doesn't bother me, and it offers an ok variety of good music and intersting small adds to the gameplay along the way to not mind the little repetetiveness. This game has also a great pick up and play feel to it. Sometimes I just don't know what to play, my mouse is far away from me and I look for a game simple (yet more elaborated than a phone game) and enjoyable while browsing my library and Sequence fast became one of those games that I would just pick up, quickly remember where I left off and get back in right away.

If you're ok/good with rhythm and looking for something different then you should absolutly buy it! Keywords: Fresh and Funny ;)

Well, it's a great little music title. It blends the rhythm gameplay of stepmania with an interesting, if repetitive, RPG story and setting to create a genuinely unique game. It is a bit too much of a grindfest, but for the price you could do a lot worse.

At first, this looks like a simple arrow-rhythm game and some RPG bits with a story thrown in. But then you start playing. The arrow-rhythm game is actually combat against a monster, with 3 screens, your spells (which decide when to trigger) defense (occasional arrows), and mana recovery (pretty much constant arrows). You jump back and forth between these 3 screens, juggling the 3 purposes. The progress of the RPG bits feel solid though not spectacular. But the story is just absolutely amazing. The pacing is perfect, with a few twists and an ending that ties back to the very beginning.
Wonderfully unique and charming rhythm RPG recommended for anyone who likes some good tunes, hype gameplay, and a captivating story.
Great game for 1.50$ or 5$
Dance Dance Revolution x 3 for your hands with RPG elements. Literally, you cannot go wrong.
The plot and dialogue is tacky and awful. It claims to offer a musical experience that is somehow different from all the other arrow-tapping games, but it really doesn't. In fact, it's a bit worse.
Clever mixture of rhythm and RPG. DDR-esque gameplay and a humourous, meta story sure to delight gamers. Offers a good challenge and opportunity for flow.
Easly the best rhytem game i have played on steam. If you enjoyed rock band or tap tap and you have a thing for rpg's, this is your game. and its only 5 bucks.

Honestly, this is a fantastic game. Buy it, on sale or otherwise. It's a unique concept, excellently excecuted. Throw in catchy music, quality voiceacting seldom seen in even big-name titles, and a well-written story with relateable characters, and you've got what might be one of my favorite games of all time.

Taking a simple DDR based rthym game and turning into an RPG combat system was a suprisingly good idea. Unfortunately the way progression in the game is very grindy, but the core combat mechanics are more than fun enough to keep you playing.
And while a simple arcade concept such as this could have easily gone with a cheesy and overly simplistic story, they went all out here, the game's got a very good story and is well voice acted.

Simply put, for the cheap price it's currently available at (or even better, free with There came an echoe) it'll provide hours of fun and a great story. Can't recommend it enough, Iridium studios are quickly becoming a studio to watch out for.

reviewText:
Games like Sequence are the reason Kickstarter and the Indie Game movement exist. It's not a perfect game, not everyone is going to enjoy it and it will never receive a lot of fame and recognition. However, for the niche audience that can appreciate it, Sequence is a game like no other.

The closest thing I can relate Sequence to is Puzzle Quest. The game doesn't play like Puzzle Quest but what that game did for Match-3 games, Sequence does for the rhythm genre. The base game has you traveling up a tower by fighting enemies, collecting their dropped items, and synthesising items such as keys, weapons and armor. Battles give you experience which will level up your stats while armor and weapons are equipable and can also improve your abilities.

Where Sequence differs from the average dungeon crawler is that combat is played out by putting you in a rhythm system similar to StepMania, if you're using a keyboard, but with three separate boards. One board is defensive, one board is for building mana and one is for casting spells. On the first board, any notes that you miss will count as damage against you so catching them defends your HP. The second board will have a constant stream of notes. Missing them doesn't hurt you but catching them restores your mana which you need to cast spells. The last board stays dormant until you cast spells, the only way to damage your opponents. When you cast a spell, it takes mana and makes you complete a short rhythm sequence. Failing it causes the spell to fail but completing it will cast that spell. While it can be a lot to juggle at once, the game does a great job of teaching you and ramping up the difficulty slowly in order to build your skills both in game and out.

The gameplay by itself is fun for a while but as the entire game is built around grinding items and EXP, it would get boring very quickly if it weren't for the well written story pushing players forward. The tone reminded me of The World Ends With You in the best possible way, but felt wholy unique. Your main character finds himself waking up in a tower with no idea how he got there. The voice of a girl named Naia tells you that you are stuck in this tower/game and you will need to make your way up 7 floors to escape so off you go. While there are some predictable moments, the story as a whole never becomes too transparent and despite a few moments when I swore I was done after one more battle, curiosity kept me pushing ever forward. The characters are all voiced as well and while none are particularly mind-blowing, it's a nice touch and the quality stayed consistent throughout. If you do find your bar set particularly high in regards to VO quality, they do have an option to turn it off as well although I doubt this will be necessary for most people.

That's not to say the game isn't without it's rough spots. For a music-based game, Sequence has a surprisingly limited soundtrack of only about 10 songs that show up in battle. This means several monsters will have you playing the same songs repeatedly. Thankfully, they aren't bad and some of them I didn't mind repeating but considering each monster all but requires multiple playthroughs anyway, don't be surprised if you wind up hearing the same song 10+ times. As that suggests too, the gameplay is simply too grindy and while item drops are pretty common, it can be irritating when you need one specific item and have to fight the same monster over and over just to move forward. Finally, the song balance is a bit odd as by the end of the game, the length of the song decided more battles for me than my HP did. It felt like very artificial difficulty (you lose if the song ends before killing the enemy) and it would have been nicer to have some of the songs be just a bit longer, especially in Floor 7. Depending on your strategy, you may not have a problem with this but it showed up several times in my game.

Overall, if you're looking for something different and enjoy music gameplay, Sequence is worth a shot.

DDR/Frequency/Amplitude with an RPG twist.\n\nIf you have ever been a fan of rhythm games, particularly those by Harmonix, you (hopefully) have come across the Frequency/Amplitude series. With its rapid track-switching gameplay, it was a unique and underappreciated entry in gaming history. Now, Sequence takes the track switching mechanic, applies simple DDR-style controls, and turns it into a monster-fighting RPG. It might sound crazy, but this is probably one of the best genre hybrids since Puzzle Fighter or Bust-a Move.

Awesome game, especially for such a low price. A lot of fun, challenging, and interesting. It takes a little bit to get the hang of, but once you do it's a major time waster.

Bit of a mixed bag, Sequence is a rhythm game about using three different playing to fight monsters.  There's the defense field in which you defend against incoming attacks by aggressors by blocking their attacks pressing the corresponding keys.  The spell field in which you cast spells with different effects such as DoT, healing, or fast recharge low damage spells.  And the mana field in which you replenish mana, which is used to cast spells, you can only have one of these fields open at a time and there is a time limit for defeating the monster, which is an interesting concept.  The monsters have a chance of dropping various items, the lower the more rare and they all give a different amount of experience. You use your experience to craft items, spell scrolls, or keys which you use to use to progress, herein lies some of the problems of the game.  It feels like a grind, just a huge grind.  You end up wasting so much time either killing the same monster over and over again to find that ONE item you need to make better gear or spells, and you can end up wasting all of that precious expereince you earned making you down on experience, although you do lose out on some items.  It just gets very very repetitive around floor four you notice none of the spells bring anything new to the table.  It doesn't help the writing isn't super compelling.  Not to mention the music is reused and the only time you feel like you're actually playing a rhythm game is when you're in the mana field, which is when the keys actually feel like they correspond to the music.  It's got cute ideas but it's riddled with flaws, it's worth checking out if you feel confident sinking money into just to get a feel for it, hey if you're into the grind and slamming on keys for 10 seconds at a time (roughly how long it takes to get your mana replensihed) then be my guest.
This could have been fun if the story didn't get in the way.\nThe core mechanic was good but each bit of story was a punishment for advancing.\n

reviewText: Really weird but kinda fun worth the $2.50 usd i spent for it.
Sequence is an utterly fantastic game, mixing elements of DDR, and magical strategic attacks with an excellent sound track.
It's like the Puzzle Quest of rhythm games!\n\nYou can play it using your keyboard, mouse + keyboard, gamepad, guitar, or even a dance pad if you have 'em.

You wouldn't think I'd like Sequence, given my proclivity for RPGs, sandbox games, and turn-based strategy.
You might, however, change your mind, not only because I led my review by saying 'you wouldn't think', but also because it is pretty much an RPG with the mechanics of a rhythem game. Which sounds sort of repellent when I say it that way, but I'll just reiterate how great it is.
For one thing, the combat mechanism is ingenious, forcing you to choose between offense, defense, and the ability to actually do anything, meaning that you can't just turtle up, you have to be doing multiple things at once. This is complicated by restricting you to a certain time limit to resolve your combats. When you factor in the occasionally crippling difficulty (especially if you joined me in suicide and started on the hardest difficulty setting)...♥♥♥♥'s hard. Which is great.
For another thing, it has a pretty decent story behind it (and not a few dramatic twists), and some quirky ARG elements behind one of the achievements, which I thought was a fun touch.
Of course the RPG elements are only in the sense that you can 'level up' and 'have an inventory', but the decision between taking levels and ensuring crafting successes is another cool touch.
I highly recommend this game if you like games with a solid story, and even more if you already like rhythm games by themselves.
I like to call the gameplay in this Wizardstep

Skip a trip to McDonalds or Starbucks or whatever, and you have enough money left to get this game.

reviewText:
This game, as an RPG, keeps you on your toes. The crafting system and leveling system is well-balanced, but a lot of grinding is required to be able to match up to later boss fights.
As a rhythm game, it's a tedious, but fun multi-tasking feature. Though it may be confusing at first, it's a blast to play once you get the hang of it.
The soundtrack is well-put together and something to move along to while playing. Also great to put in your music library!

The game, as a whole, is a great experience! Highly recommend this to any RPG and/or rhythm game player!

An extremely novel idea executed very well. The story is so-so, and the voice acting feels like it was done by bored devs, but the gameplay and audio really make this a win. It is a mixture of a rythm game and an RPG, which pits you against an oppenent to music where you must hit notes on your gamepad/keyboard in rythm on one of 3 boards to win. 1 board gains mana, 1 casts various spells, and 1 defends on attack. Balancing which spells you take into fights, which boards you focus on, and handling the special abilities that bosses throw at you is a lot of fun. It doesn't hurt that the musical selection is also very good.

Interesting concept with the 3 different screens of arrows you have to switch through.  Tries very hard to be an 'offbeat RPG' like Puzzle Quest, but ultimately the RPG elements are unimportant and the story sequences feature a bunch of flat and emotionless voice actors trying to be hip and witty.

If fanboys of the Matrix got together and tried to film another Matrix with no budget and an all-new script they wrote themselves, the dialogue would probably sound like it does in this game.  It's painful.  If you watch the trailer and listen to one of the devs trying way too hard to be hip while describing the game, you'll understand why it turned out this way.

Sadly the music is a low point as well.  You would think in a game built entirely on timing, music and rhythm that the audio tracks would be a high point, but all of these tracks feel like recycled DDR tunes.

If at some point in your life you *really* enjoyed finger DDR or Stepmania, you might like this game.  Otherwise, skip it.
Epic Combo for Music-Rhythm and RPG!\nIncredibly addictive and awesome writing and voice acting!\n10/10!

A prettty good comedic RPG game with music elements.  The game has take some ways to mix it up and make it more interesting from the outset.

There's a good set of electronica (?) to enjoy.

I'm kind of curious to find a DDR pad for this.
Awesome, like DDR + a simple rpg and story mode.  Anyone who gave this a low score is expecting way too much.

One of the most unique games I've ever played, I really enjoyed it.  Randomness can occasionally be frustrating, especially in synthing items since they cost experience,.  This can result in the game occasionally becoming a bit grindy, especially if you are a completionist.  Still really enjoyed it.  Also, it is extremely cheap, extremely great value for the price they are asking for it.

Rather unqiue rythem game, if you've ever played stepmaina using a keyboard you should recongize the combat system a bit.  You basically get three feilds, one to rebuild mana, one to block attacks from your oppenent, and finally the last feild is for attacking with spells, all of which is timed to the tempo of the song.  Each spell uses a different sequence of steps as well. Each level you are collecting ingredents to make a key to continue on, or other items to help you in your quest. The caracthers are fully voiced, and are very charming and humorous.  At the price of some starbucks coffee or some meal you can't really go wrong.

Then you are certainly qualified) and really, really good art. Oh, and everything is voiced. EVERYTHING. And it is great.

Oh, and when I was talking about witty writing? Every single item has a description. Most of those descriptions will make you laugh, or at least do that I can't laugh in public but this is hilarious stop staring at me" thing. You know the one I mean."

Very enjoyable rhythm based rpg game, makes battle very active and very rewarding.  Definitely worth playing if you enjoy rhythm games or just like rpg type games with an interesting story.

Rhythm game meets old-school turn-based RPG. This is every bit as peculiar as it sounds. The music is slick, much of it licensed from capable hands such as the wonderful Ronald Jenkees, and the gameplay can be quite punishing on higher difficulty levels. I would recommend playing this game witha controller, and indeed have not checked if it is possible (or enjoyable) without.

You'll be switching between three sets of scrolling DDR style arrows: one for incoming damage that is blocked by accurate hits, another (typically containing the most difficult pieces of the song) recharges your Mana pool on accurate hits, and a third for spells. Spells are cast with the right analog stick, which (after a delay) sends down a specific rhythmic snippet that changes it's tempo to fit the current song (the specific direction of arrows changes every time you cast, and the difficulty level also changes the spells, making the more complicated versions of the same basic rhytmic idea).

The game has you madly flying between these screens to defeat enemies before the song ends--it's one wierd, wild ride and it's well worth it. Battles are tense and fascinating, and there's a lot of room for varied play styles in your spell collection of choice as well as a lot of room for growth within the broad difficulty span. There's even a practice mode where you can just play through the full songs in a more standard rhthym game format. Highly recommended.
A brilliant mix of RPG and rhythm games, with great electronic music and bloody good art.

With unique gameplay and an engaging story, Sequence is a gem among indie games. The intelligent, fully-voiced story, great visuals and soundtrack and the interesting blend of two otherwise distinct genres make this game more than worth its price.

Sequence is a fun but simple DDR-style rhythm game with just enough uniqueness to keep the 10 hours it takes to reach 100% completion interesting. Its voice acted narrative, level-up system, and loot and inventory elements help it rise above its fundamentally repetitive nature. Several NPCs have some really great dialogue, which kept me eager to push through to the next story scene.\n\nIt would have been nice to have a lot more variety in the music, but thankfully the handful of tracks, especially Ronald Jankee’s work, are all great. Considering only two people made the game (and it only cost me $1.25), Sequence was and is a memorable experience worth playing.

This is an amazing game -- no joke -- you owe it to yourself to play this game.  At five bones you simply can't beat this (although I picked it up for less than two bones during the Xmas sale).  It's worth owning for the soundtrack alone.  Buy this game.  You won't be disappointed.
With awesome electronic tunes and rhythmic gameplay challenging you at every point, this game is amazing for the price
A rhythm-based RPG, quite rare. Extremely witty dialogue, interesting crafting system, and awesome music. This is my gem of the holiday sale. If you appreciate RPG's or rhythm-based games, buy this.

I was sceptical with this game. I can DDR, but don't like stepmania or any of those keyboard-equivalents. Having said that, this is pretty addictive and the RPG element stands out. It isn't explained very well in the description - you're basically being set up to fail on the 3 boards, you can't possibly hit all the arrows, and that's fine (one to stop being hit, one to get mana to cast spells, one to successfully cast a spell - most arrows are on the mana board, which doesn't matter if you miss arrows until you need a refill).\n\nIt's a very bizarre concept that somehow works. You get items, make recipes to get new items, eventually make a key" to advance to the next level. There's 8 levels to the tower
recommended: some of which you'll fight more than once (and you'll be okay with it). You're not playing for the music here
hoursPlayed: the music is just the world you're fighting in.\n\nVery solid $5 game."

reviewText: This game is amazing. If a game that combines rhythm game and RPG appeals to you then this game would be something to look at even if that combination of genre wasn't so rare.\n\nFirst off to all the people who aren't scared off from thinking of potential problems or weirdness already, it's not just let's smash these genres together". It's very functional as a rhythm game and they made that part of gameplay the "battle" portion of the RPG. You switch between "fields" to either defend against attacks
date: cast spells or regain mana. The balance of strength of attacks and difficulty pulling them off feels nice and natural and the game overall feels just wonderfully made. Like any RPG you might need to grind a little but just remember to pay attention to getting good equipment and good spell usage and it shouldn't get too bad. I think the only negative I can really think about gameplay is there isn't any "turn based" alternative for anyone that isn't physically capable of playing a timing based game
recommended: but for the rest of it it's good to go.\n\nMusic and visual aesthetics might depend a bit on individual taste to say for sure but I personally loved both in this game.  The story is awesome too
hoursPlayed: unlike a lot of other RPG's it doesn't give you a ton of story which works since plenty of the interest comes in the mystery and uncertainty. You get just a few cutscenes every floor
voteText: long enough to enjoy the strange characters but not so long you forget you're playing a video game. Trust me there's not really any throw away characters.\n\nSaddly as much as I'd like to go on I don't know how much deeper I can dig without risking any spoilers or rambling on too much

I've been playing Before the Echo for years, and still wholeheartedly recommend it.  Several years back it was released as an Xbox Indie game called Sequence.  Controller, dancepad, and guitar support.  Not too much later it was ported to PC in all its glory.  I bought it again because, why not?  Although the voice acting and story get a lot of criticism, I love them both.  Maybe its just my kind of humor, but I find all of it both clever and charming.\n\nMy only complaint about the game is depending on your dificulty of choice, you can get some harsh difficulty spikes right after you pass the point you are no longer allowed to chance your difficulty.  Be warned, but otherwise this game is loads of fun.  RPG plus Rhythm game with loads of style and witty dialogue thrown in.  Also, the creator voices the main character and honstly, I think he does a terrific job.  Well done, all around.  The game is well worth the price tag.

A neat concept that supports alternative control methods to spice up the gameplay, with clever dialogue.\n\nUnfortunatley the game drags out the experience by slathering the campaign with RPG elements, forcing replay of the same tunes to progress rather than having a shorter, sweeter game.
Highly recomend it if you like rhythm games. It's pretty challenging and has a quirky, yet interesting story

The best rhythm game you'll ever play in your life.  Combines the falling notes element of rhythm games with some great RPG elements, which create a real, unique experience.  My only complaint is the grinding you need to do the unlock everything, though it's not really required.  Also, although I really enjoy the music in the game, by the end of the game I had pretty much heard enough, as the number of tracks are somewhat limited.  Still, a great game that's worth a pick-up.

This game is a perfectly synthesized mixture of DanceDanceRevolution (with Keyboard controls) and a RPG looting and crafting system. The entertaining story is accompanied by very good voice acting. A very round experience with great potential of addicting you instantly.

hoursPlayed: true

reviewText:
Games like Sequence are the reason Kickstarter and the Indie Game movement exist. It's not a perfect game, not everyone is going to enjoy it and it will never receive a lot of fame and recognition. However, for the niche audience that can appreciate it, Sequence is a game like no other.

The closest thing I can relate Sequence to is Puzzle Quest. The game doesn't play like Puzzle Quest but what that game did for Match-3 games, Sequence does for the rhythm genre. The base game has you traveling up a tower by fighting enemies, collecting their dropped items, and synthesising items such as keys, weapons and armor. Battles give you experience which will level up your stats while armor and weapons are equipable and can also improve your abilities.

Where Sequence differs from the average dungeon crawler is that combat is played out by putting you in a rhythm system similar to StepMania, if you're using a keyboard, but with three separate boards. One board is defensive, one board is for building mana and one is for casting spells. On the first board, any notes that you miss will count as damage against you so catching them defends your HP. The second board will have a constant stream of notes. Missing them doesn't hurt you but catching them restores your mana which you need to cast spells. The last board stays dormant until you cast spells, the only way to damage your opponents. When you cast a spell, it takes mana and makes you complete a short rhythm sequence. Failing it causes the spell to fail but completing it will cast that spell. While it can be a lot to juggle at once, the game does a great job of teaching you and ramping up the difficulty slowly in order to build your skills both in game and out.

The gameplay by itself is fun for a while but as the entire game is built around grinding items and EXP, it would get boring very quickly if it weren't for the well written story pushing players forward. The tone reminded me of The World Ends With You in the best possible way, but felt wholy unique. Your main character finds himself waking up in a tower with no idea how he got there. The voice of a girl named Naia tells you that you are stuck in this tower/game and you will need to make your way up 7 floors to escape so off you go. While there are some predictable moments, the story as a whole never becomes too transparent and despite a few moments when I swore I was done after one more battle, curiosity kept me pushing ever forward. The characters are all voiced as well and while none are particularly mind-blowing, it's a nice touch and the quality stayed consistent throughout. If you do find your bar set particularly high in regards to VO quality, they do have an option to turn it off as well although I doubt this will be necessary for most people.

That's not to say the game isn't without it's rough spots. For a music-based game, Sequence has a surprisingly limited soundtrack of only about 10 songs that show up in battle. This means several monsters will have you playing the same songs repeatedly. Thankfully, they aren't bad and some of them I didn't mind repeating but considering each monster all but requires multiple playthroughs anyway, don't be surprised if you wind up hearing the same song 10+ times. As that suggests too, the gameplay is simply too grindy and while item drops are pretty common, it can be irritating when you need one specific item and have to fight the same monster over and over just to move forward. Finally, the song balance is a bit odd as by the end of the game, the length of the song decided more battles for me than my HP did. It felt like very artificial difficulty (you lose if the song ends before killing the enemy) and it would have been nicer to have some of the songs be just a bit longer, especially in Floor 7. Depending on your strategy, you may not have a problem with this but it showed up several times in my game.

Overall, if you're looking for something different and enjoy music gameplay, Sequence is worth a shot.

A rhythm rpg game with a level up system and a crafting element is a brief summary, however the story and characters are flat and unengaging, I keep meaning to go back and try to finish the game but never quite get there.

This is a great game!

It's like stepmania on PC with RPG elements and a very selfaware and sarcastic humor. It does not take itself very serious and has its unique dialouge and humor style which is awesome!

But it's well worth the money!

Well, it's a great little music title. It blends the rhythm gameplay of stepmania with an interesting, if repetitive, RPG story and setting to create a genuinely unique game. It is a bit too much of a grindfest, but for the price you could do a lot worse.
Awesome game! Combination of Guitar Hero -eqsue button pressing, spell casting and a great soundtrack. Great fun, I play far too much.
This is an awesome rhythm action/rpg hybrid.  Totally worth $5, or you can wait for it to go on sale.

This game was that summer fling that you could never forget. I don't know why I bought it and when it was over a piece of me went with it.
Truely one of the few inde games you will apreciate.

Sure I like some fun rythm games every now and then and maybe some games that will challenge me to be a better player, but what keeps me hooked until the end is that storyline. I'm all about the feels and this game's storyline delivers it.

STORY: 10/10
Everything about this game feels like a budget game, but the voice acting and the music and thought put into the story developement drove it home for me. I truely felt like I was experiencing all of the hard work each person put into this game I even took a moment of pause and watched the credits. its that good.

GAMEPLAY: 8/10
Lets be honest, rythm games are very hard to be creative with. You can only do so much to make a person appriciate the music and stay with the beat before it becomes too difficult or too generic.  They did a great job with attempting to give you more than just a beat to hit some buttons with, they gave you enemies to hammer down and spell combos to add a twist to the mix of some pretty good beats.

At first, juggling through 3 different rythm windows in a battle along with a timer taunting you to the very nano second to hammer out the best moves orElseUlolFail@life can be intimidating, but it actually makes a ton of sense and you feel like youre really battling it out with some baddies while head bobbing to the beat. For what they had to work with, this is something to really try out for yourself.

ART: 8/10
This isnt some blockbuster game that had millions of dollars backing it along with teams of graphic designers, so dont expect amazing CG movie like animations here ladies. The art for each stage is very unique and even melds with the music and the tone of the story. The characters do seem budget like, but by no means are they generic.

REPLAY: 5/10
Sometimes the replay has to justify the price, and this game definately had the opportunity to get some DLCs going of side quests, a battle arena for other players, hell even an after the tower storyline. I really did enjoy the game for what its worth, but after playing the entire thing including the extras in the first run I wished there was something more to comeback to later on.


Conclusion: I know you will pass buy this game as your browsing through the store looking for a quick fix and overlook it. I honestly dont recall what made me buy it in the first place, but I am glad I did and I am pretty sure you will be too. If youre that strapped, its just 5 bucks and you get a lot more bang for your buck from this game than you would for whatever 5 bucks can get you nowadays. Pick up this game and enjoy the adventure.

A bizarre, but highly addictive combination of game styles. The dialogue is oddly engaging, and left me wondering what would happen next. Reasonaby priced to boot. Definitely recommended for fans of rhythm games and titles with level-up systems.
Awesome Game. $5. That is all I have to say.

This game took me totally by suprise. I bought it for 99p in a sale one time not expecting much - but holy cow, it's one of the most unique games I've played. In a cross between an RPG and keyboard version of DDR, you're a guy who's in a tower of killer monsters with no explanation as to why. The bosses have unique personalities and playing styles which means that as you advance the game never gets too boring. The only problem I might have with the game is it's lack of variety in the music department, but it's only a minor quibble for such a cheap game. Buy it now! It's that good!
A neat music game with a focus on plot... weird I know. The writing is awful but the story ain't bad and the game itself + music is really great. Bought it for $1.99

You will hate it.  Does that say something about you or me? Because I love it. It's amazing. But, you have to ask your(my)self, who, exactly, am I recommending this TO? (nay, to whom am I recommending this) Because, do you recommend something for things YOU like-- or things you think your FRIENDS will like. That's the crux, I suppose. Hm, but I guess the goal is to find friends who have similar tastes.  That's why they're your friends... (or, if not, I'm doing all of this totally wrong...) So, I guess this is to say, if you're a TRUE friend, you will love this game.  No pressure.  But, then again, what the hell does my opinion matter.  You're your own person, and your opinions are your own.  So recommend all you want?  Yeah, that's what we do.

Extremely well crafted game. Love the beat/music dance-pad like game mechanic mixed with RPG elements led by a young college-kid protagonist and female narrator who don't take the game to seriously. Recommended. I give it a 4/5.

I absolutely loved this! I loved the music which never got boring and tiresome when I was grinding for those rare items. I never had an issue with the crafting, I thought it was pretty inventive becasue it gets the player to make decisions on the items they absolutely need and then to be prepared for the crafting. I thought that the battle system was INSANE! The amount of thought and timing that goes into each battle is awesome.\nNow, my few issues were that A. It was too short and B. Some of the drop rates were a little too out there to benefit from. I mean sure there is THAT item, but it wasn't worth it and it was too much of a spike at the point when I got it (just before the final boss fight for the 6th time because SO ANNOYING)\nAll in all 9/10, you guys did AMAZING

Before the Echo is like this weird Rhythm game and rpg rolled into one. You play the game by matching Arrows in three different fields. Defense blocks attacks, There's an attack field where you need to hit all the arrows to cast spells. Then there is the mana pool where you replenish your mana for more spells. The thing is you queue your spells up on your own. So you have to either take a few hits while you get a spell off on the enemy or maybe you'll find that gap in the enemy's attack pattern. Besides that the game has a ton of other rpg elements like monster drops, item synthesis, equipment, learning new spells and more.

I also enjoy the voice acting and all the snarky sarasm that goes on between the guy you play and Naia the girl over the intercom. I was really laughing at the first boss encounter poor old percival was offended by my words. Then again he was asking for it.

I say pick this up if you like rhythm games and want a splash of rpg stuff to go with it.
Totally recommend this game.

In the way that Puzzle Quest is an RPG with Bejewled for combat, Sequence is an RPG with Stepmania for combat.  Addictive, fun, absolutely worth the low price.  I beat it in about 10 hours with essentially full achievement completion, so if I were bulldozing through I could probably do it in less, but it's a great way to burn an hour or two a day for a couple weeks.
Music gets dull, but overall it's pretty entertaining when you only have 15 minutes to get a game in.
Very fun, great soundtrack, interesting story and cheap. Worth the time and money.

As someone who's been playing Dance Dance Revolution emulators on PC since 2003, I drooled at the chance to try this.  I was not disappointed.  In the same way that Puzzle Quest was a role-playing adventure using Bejeweled as its combat system, Sequence is a fun, genuinely hilarious quest that has you playing DDR to represent combat.  This is a lot more creative than it sounds.  You're faced with three streams of arrows; one for offense, one for defense, and one for regaining mana used to fuel your attacks.  Constantly shifting between streams, organizing your list of spells, and seeking out rare materials for crafting new gear is made even more fun by the top quality music, great voice acting, and a script that is much funnier than you'd ever expect.  The $5 price is yet another reason you should add this to your collection.  Don't pass this up.

I gave this game a second chance. This game is much easier played with a controller than a keyboard since the game has some fairly complex controls. The object of the game is to grind songs by defeating the same monsters over and over to make keys to progress from level to level. It's kinda like RPG meets Stepmania. The music is not bad though it gets recycled a lot. The best part about this game is the humor. The voice acting and cutscenes are funny and the flavor text on items will make you chuckle.

reviewText: Great music, good voice acting -- especially for an indie venture -- and a very nicely written story. The story is intriguing, especially later into the game, and the characters are hilarious. Dialogue is snarky and well-written, and had me laughing a lot. In my opinion, the only thing truly lacking was the gameplay, which was a little weak. I only played on medium, and it was challenging by the end of the game, but the content was repetitive.This isn't so much a problem of difficulty, but more a byproduct of the game's small pool of resources compared to many other rhythm games.\n\nAll in all, as a cheap-♥♥♥ game it's a nice buy. It makes for an especially nice deal during Steam Sales and the like.

It's an RPG with a DDR-esque battle system. Having three simultaneous DDR-esque streams going -- one for offense, one for defense, and one for healing -- at all times during battle keeps things from going stale and allows the player freedom to strategize. If you like rhythm games, this is definitely a good one to get. It doesn't hurt that the writing and characters are also excellent.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vIvlw7S6fCA

This game's Very Positive rating at the time of this review really boggles my mind. It's not that the game is bad, rather that its an idea who's implementation seems inherently flawed.\n\nThe base mechanic of the game is the traditional press one or more of the 4 directions on the beat as instructed". However
date: the twist is that you have three panels of arrows to rotate between and timing your presses correctly on them has different effects. There's your mana regen panel where each correct press earns you a little mana to cast spells. There's another that represents spellcasting where successfully landing a series of presses will cast a spell (more on this later). The last one represents defense where a sequence of arrows represents the enemy's attack; if you miss any here you take damage.\n\nThe problem is that the defense panel's arrows (i.e. the enemy's attacks) occur at random
recommended: but you have to manually trigger your spellcast sequences. You may already see the issue here: you build mana
hoursPlayed: cast an attack spell
voteText: and arrows start to fall in the spell cast panel and defense panel simultaneously. The game's prescribed cure for this is to constantly keep up a "barrier" spell which effectively mutes the enemy. So the game requires you to continually recast this barrier spell so that you can actually cast the spells you want in between each barrier cast. In my opinion this is a kludge of a game mechanic. You get involved with a whole lot of busy work just to occasionally do something meaningful. Perhaps it all gets a bit smoother with some practice
helpfulPercent: but whats to engage you enough to want to get that good?\n\nI found a majority of the music to be ignorable at best. I've enjoyed some of Ronald Jenkees' music
votesHelpful: but what's offered here I'd be reluctant to classify as even B-side music. The dialog is atrocious
votesFunny: and the graphics are the kind of crappy animatics that have now become standard fair in a sea of indie game dev mediocrity. The game would be perfectly suited for two hands on the keyboard
commentsCount: but I was forced into using a controller. (Oh I hope this wasn't just because I had a controller plugged into my PC; I'm not going back!)\n\nPerhaps worst yet is that the game devolves into a grind as each enemy you face has the chance to drop (at most?) one of three items of increasingly rarer chances to drop. You can face an enemy multiple times (enjoying the same music each time!) to get all items from an enemy. Why? Did the game need a time sink like this? Again
column16: its more poor game design that not only contributes nothing fun
column17: but actually contributes frustration.\n\nI really wanted to like this game. I had it on my wishlist as soon as it was released and bought it while it was still named Sequence. Despite the game's somewhat novel concept

reviewText:
I played Before the Echo on Linux using a Steam Controller, and had a great time. The concept is simple, but well executed, and playing with the Steam Controller's two touchpads was perfect for such a precision game; I enjoyed not having to press buttons all the time but having the possibility to just touch the right area; so I'd recommend the config I shared to any player using a Steam Controller ;)

The music is nice and the dialogs are witty, and all that with relatively good voice acting. There are some good 12+ hours of gameplay on the normal difficulty, plus some cool bonuses and optional hidden ending for the hardcore looters.

For this price, it's definitely a good buy, even if you're not particularly interested in rhythm games in the first place (that's my case, and I still really enjoyed Before the Echo).

A great RPG and a great rhythm game which offers a challenge to both hardcore and casual gamers. The story is interesting enough and the dialogue (as well as the item descriptions) contains a lot of humor. For this price it would be a crime to not buy this game.
Cool rhythm rpg game with some catchy beats!  The writing is a little annoying sometimes, but it's not that bad.

Dialog = 10/10\n\nThe banter in this game was amazing! Absolutely loved it! The sass from Niah is awesome! XD It does take a bit of getting used to switching between screens while adjusting to different patterns. There is a bit of grinding but overall this game was very fun to play :3
YES. I can finally play this on my mac.  Fun, relaxing, love it.
This is a great and innovative musical-RPG game that must be played by every fans of music games :)

I'm conflcted in reviewing this game, because I both enjoy it and resent some of its features.

First, the good points:
+ Nice music
+ Fun gameplay, has a nice flow to it
+ Love the variety of spells and possibilities for spell combos
+ The narrative is neat and has entertaining humor and characters
+ Pretty artwork, and solid-looking characters


Now the not-so-good:
- Not much song variety. New levels and challenges for unlocking spells tend to recycle songs from previous levels.
- Item crafting is done by sacrificing some exp. This in itself isnt horrible, but when paired with the tiny song selection, repeating the same fights over and over again to craft your armor and weapons and keys to unlock the next level all while trying to maintain a level that allows you to continue playing comfortably becomes tedious.
- In short, grinding becomes pretty much mandatory.
- Not much selection in craftable weapons and armor. Each level supplies you with crafting recipes for one armor and weapon item at its beginning. Additional items can sometimes be dropped by enemies, but I have rarely found these helpful. When I saw the crafting screens in the trailer, I was hoping there would be more variety in items for the player; a build with a ton of attack and no defense, or a ton of mana but not much health would be interesting challenges to make repeating songs less tedious.

Additionally, controllers are supported by the game, but only 360 controllers as of right now. I used the program ds4windows to make my ps4 controller compatible with it (running on Win8.1), and I have seen others find supporting programs for different controllers. Using a controller makes for comfortable gameplay.


Overall, I'm not sure I whether I would recommend this game. The core concept is interesting and the spells are fun. Playing the faster-paced songs is a blast. However, the game suffers from a tiny playlist which turns some floors into drudgery and this track again?" rather than keeping it a fun

It's and interesting game with a blend of genres. I used to play a lot of DDR and Stepmania on PC when I was younger and I was really hoping this would scratch that itch for me. Alas, although I really liked the humor, this falls really flat for me. I expect better responses and controls from a rhythm game and this did not have either. Give me more monsters to fight, not the same few to fight over and over on each floor. I think I had too high expectations for this game but for me it is a no go. I can't recommend this coming from a DDR snob like me.\n\n2/5 Fun for some, but not for me.
Great rhythm game, with pretty good rpg elements and funny dialogue.

I'm not even a huge fan of rhythm games, but I seriously cannot recommend Sequence enough. It's funny and fun -- I originally just played it simply because there was a Winter achievement for it, but now I plan to beat the entire game.
For a 3$ game, I was pleasantly surprised. Simple, fast, fun, nice music. There's the story that takes a big oooook
recommended: but overall a nice addition. B"
hoursPlayed: December 31, 2011

reviewText:
Sequence is a rhythm RPG, which is, in and of itself, an interesting concept. It delivers this with surprisingly unique gameplay, an interesting story, and an excellent, albeit limited, selection of music to play along to.

In terms of gameplay, it's not unlike DDR in that you have four arrows that you have to hit to the rhythm as they reach the bottom of the screen while music plays in the background. However, the similarities stop there. Combat involves rotating between three screens: your damage screen, your mana screen, and your spell screen. The damage screen represents incoming attacks from your opponent, and each arrow missed on this screen will result in your health taking a hit. The spell screen is used for all of the abilities in the game, where you must select what type of spell you want to perform and then hit every arrow in that spell for it to succeed. The mana screen grants mana, for casting spells, with every arrow that is hit. As a result, the game turns into a very interesting experience where you have to time spells so that you don't take too much damage, and prioritize each of these screens so that you can keep yourself alive and deplete your enemy's health bar before the song ends.

When a battle concludes, loot is dropped. This loot can be used to craft specific items on each floor, such as new weapons and equipment, a key to get to the next level, and a few other secrets that are best observed within the game. Especially towards the end, there are some very interesting items that can be crafted, and a lot of secrets and hidden content. I highly recommend crafting every item in the game, waiting until after the credits, and then exploring a bit more based on what you learn. This game quickly becomes intriguing, and knows how to deliver on it.

One point of criticism I have for this game is that, if you're looking to craft all of the items in the game, it can get a little repetitive. Each enemy has the same song every time you fight them, and when you get close to the end, there are a few items that have pretty low drop rates. Having to repeat the same fight fifteen times in a row, as a result, can get a drab. Luckily, it's not the exact same pattern of arrows every time, and the gameplay is engaging and fun enough that I didn't find this to be much of an issue, but it is something worth mentioning.

If you're a fan of rhythm games, Sequence brings a twist on a traditional formula that makes it feel almost entirely new. I'm glad I put in all of the time that I did, and I think a lot of people would be surprised at how much they enjoy it.
I loathe rhythm games and thoroughly enjoyed Sequence.
This is a fantastic game... it mashes rhythm and rpg elements together and does it very well.

So far it's an awesome game! This game is a pleasent surprise, one of my favorite games I bought during winter sale (though even at full price it would be a good buy).

It's fresh and funny. The concept of a rhythm game mixt with RPG is well executed. The voice acting is great and I Iove the light and humorious dialogues. The more I discover about this game the more I want to keep playing.

Even if it's a great game, I wouldn't recommend it to people who have difficulties with rhythm (didn't look through all the difficulty levels though). As an exemple, it isn't a game for my brother... but he does enjoy watching me play it. Also, some might find it a bit repetitive, I could understand why but so is every RPG or RPG-like game.

Personnaly, it doesn't bother me, and it offers an ok variety of good music and intersting small adds to the gameplay along the way to not mind the little repetetiveness. This game has also a great pick up and play feel to it. Sometimes I just don't know what to play, my mouse is far away from me and I look for a game simple (yet more elaborated than a phone game) and enjoyable while browsing my library and Sequence fast became one of those games that I would just pick up, quickly remember where I left off and get back in right away.

If you're ok/good with rhythm and looking for something different then you should absolutly buy it! Keywords: Fresh and Funny ;)

Phenomenal rhythm game. Really, the most enjoyable I've ever played besides DDR. It suffers from....bizarre dialogue and plot, occasionally funny, sometimes offensive in odd ways, but the design of the game is truly great. If you like rhythm games this is an absolute must.

It's a compulsively playable rhythm game made by Jonathan Blow wannabes. So the actual game part is pretty good, but between rounds you have to sit through ten minute long talking head cutscenes featuring irritatingly precious Diablo Cody style dialogue.
Could use a few more songs and higher drop percentages on the random loot, but overall a fun and innovative rthym/role-playing game
Not really my cup of tea, and it's kind of grindy, but it's very well done with lot's of stuff to do. Recommended if you like rhythm games.
Fun gameplay, decent music, and awful voice acting. Sounds like something some college kids acted out in their dorm.
A rhythm game / RPG mashup; the soundtrack is varied with some very catchy tunes, and the controls are quite easy to get the hang of. Very unique and very enjoyable.

Quite awesome, to be completely honest. Some longtime stepmania players may find it hard to adapt to lane switching, and the arrows which are now coded for game mechanics reasons (like skills, incoming damage amounts), rather than based on beat type. This in particular can make some things (like skill unlock challenges) much harder than you may be used to, for interface reasons. Still, the gameplay is quite solid, the dialog and characters, while campy, is very enjoyable, and the game overall was more than worth a summer sale purchase price.
A very strange game, but I like it. You should get it if you like rhythm or rpg games or both. A little humour here and there. It's a good deal for $5.
Got it when it was on sale for a buck something. I can attest that it's even worth the normal price. a rhythm game with decent humor and a RPG like feel. A MUST HAVE.
Awesome game for anyone who likes StepMania.

A great indie game. Every other day a game tester demands more innovation in the gaming world. Well, here it is: Tap tap-style rhythm game meets RPG. And this game only takes the best of both. Playing Sequence is a delight. Not only do the mechanics work extrordinarily well, the story is surprisingly entertaining, too; quite funny as well as suspenseful, and even a little thought-provoking. The music is superb.\n\nI love this game. It's fantastic.
Interesting mesh between a rhythm game and an RPG. Ronald Jenkees is fantastic. Best rhythm game out there.

The Puzzle Quest of DDR/Stepmania. A combination that surprisingly works. All with great voice acting and a decent story tying it all together. The soundtrack is also great, but it would greatly benefit from more tracks. The concept of dealing with three sets at once seems daunting, but once you play it, everything just clicks and every battle is a series of rhythmic keystrokes. I grabbed it on sale for $1 and I can't argue with the value. As a fan of DDR and RPG's it was certainly worth a shot and I'm not disappointed. Played it to completion in 2 days. It does get a little grindy if you're trying to 100% the game and it does get pretty difficult (especially if you're not accustomed to the genre), but it's certainly worth a shot.
A great, funny and very different game. The rhythm-game/classic-RPG mash-up works really well even though it does feature quite a bit of grinding. Playing it with a controller is advised

I love the music but I have no rythm. The gameplay is interesting in that you have to split your attention to attack, defend, and harvest mana. But it is not a hard game. It also has the basic RPG elements. This gets my Seal of Uniqueness.
A-M-A-Z-I-N-G

Imagine playing DDR with your hands and managing three machines at the same time.  That is pretty much the core of this game.  If you like rhythm games that consist of four directions, you might like this.  Essentially, you're juggling three DDR boards, but it's not like there's constant arrows (it does get harder, mind you).  One board is like charging up your mana.  One board is strictly for inputting attacks.  The remaining board is to defend against enemy attacks.\n\nOh, and I think there's a story here, too, but nobody cares.
Grindy. If you love rythm games, you might like this one, because that's how you grind.

reviewText: Nice game if you like RPGs, but also like stepmania type games. Combines the 2 nicely.

Considering that this is a blend of rhythm games and RPGs, my two favorite genres, I don't know why it didn't catch my eye on day one. The general gameplay involves switching between three play fields - one to gain mana to cast spells, one to actually use the spells, and one to defend against enemy attacks. It's the kind of concept that must be played to get a good idea of, but let me tell you, it's great. Most of the gameplay music is by Ronald Jenkees, who I now know to be a fantastic artist. While the ending is a bit lackluster on all accounts - a tad 'what the heck?', a bit of open-endedness, even on the secret ending, and a special achievement that might or might not really bug you (I was fine with it, and rather liked it) - Sequence/Before The Echo is an indie game that you need to buy right this second. Just be ready for tons of horrible puns.

This game combines Rythm with RPG and it does it so well that I would heartly recommend this to anyone even remotely interested. Who wouldn't pick this up at such a price, and I got like 18 hours of gameplay out of one playtrough.
It's worth a buy!

Had this game recommended to me as a good music game hybrid, and was pleasantly surprised.  I'm not usually an RPG fan, but this game is enjoyable so far and there's no question that I'll see it through to the end.

As a long-time DDR/stepmania player, I stepped quite easily into hard mode.  The charts themselves are still pretty easy for me, and I can easily get 100% while unlocking spells.  However, during regular gameplay, coordinating switching between panes with hitting notes is a new and interesting challenge.

The biggest downside so far is the lack of content.  The soundtrack, while well-made, is extremely limited, and you'll end up hearing the same handful of songs over and over (so far maybe a half dozen songs in the first 4/7 floors of the tower, compared to dozens/hundreds in your average true rhythm game).  That coupled with the fact that I'm better than halfway through the game in under 4 hours suggests that this game won't have replay value.

Other thoughts:
- The art is somewhat low-res (720p?) and you can't change resolutions.  You can choose full screen or windowed though.  Not something I notice during gameplay, but nowadays I'd expect full HD (or preferably vector) art.
- So far I've only gotten one defensive spell and it's not that powerful.  There's a huge emphasis on attack-heavily-and-occasionally-heal with not much in the way of actually defending.  Some battles you can coast through without using the defense pane much at all, so it's not equally balanced throughout.
- A lot of the items/spells seem ignorable in general, unless you're a compulsive completionist like I am.
- Each floor of the tower has 3 different enemy battles (each with 3 different item drops), plus a boss battle.
- It's interesting that the item drop probabilities are shown, that way you can quantify how bad your luck is when grinding.  Sure, I got the 35% item in 3 of my last 4 battles, but I only got one of the 85% item that I need three of.  Haha.
- The boss battles don't seem to be replayable, but they do unlock new songs when you complete them that will be used in the higher levels of battle.
- Most people complaining about the name change (from Sequence") have no idea how trademark law works
date: or why companies are obligated to protect their trademarks.\n\nOverall
recommended: this game is well worth that 99c sale price
hoursPlayed: but it seems like something I'll play through once and then forget about.  I absolutely love the concept
voteText: but it needs more content for sure."

reviewText: Really intresting story, unique gameplay and good, original music. Really good title.
Well worth the price (especially at 75% off), even if you're not into rhythm games that much. The humor in the plot sells it alone. (Game does not have much replayability, though!)
A criminally underrated game, the gameplay is addictive and the story (though impossibly cheesy) is really engaging.

Before the Echo is like this weird Rhythm game and rpg rolled into one. You play the game by matching Arrows in three different fields. Defense blocks attacks, There's an attack field where you need to hit all the arrows to cast spells. Then there is the mana pool where you replenish your mana for more spells. The thing is you queue your spells up on your own. So you have to either take a few hits while you get a spell off on the enemy or maybe you'll find that gap in the enemy's attack pattern. Besides that the game has a ton of other rpg elements like monster drops, item synthesis, equipment, learning new spells and more.

I also enjoy the voice acting and all the snarky sarasm that goes on between the guy you play and Naia the girl over the intercom. I was really laughing at the first boss encounter poor old percival was offended by my words. Then again he was asking for it.

I say pick this up if you like rhythm games and want a splash of rpg stuff to go with it.
It's really a beautifull game!\nI would never thought it could be such a fantastic game, really i love it I want more like this!
rpg meets ddr.. i likes it

The hidden humor in the item description made me laugh a few times. The vocals were superb and the artstyle was magnificent. I would seriously suggest this game.

Before the Echo is like this weird Rhythm game and rpg rolled into one. You play the game by matching Arrows in three different fields. The thing is you queue your spells up on your own. So you have to either take a few hits while you get a spell off on the enemy or maybe you'll find that gap in the enemy's attack pattern. I also enjoy the voice acting and all the snarky sarasm that goes on between the guy you play and Naia the girl over the intercom. I was really laughing at the first boss encounter poor old percival was offended by my words. Then again he was asking for it.

I played Before the Echo on Linux using a Steam Controller, and had a great time. The concept is simple, but well executed, and playing with the Steam Controller's two touchpads was perfect for such a precision game; I enjoyed not having to press buttons all the time but having the possibility to just touch the right area; so I'd recommend the config I shared to any player using a Steam Controller ;)

The music is nice and the dialogs are witty, and all that with relatively good voice acting. There are some good 12+ hours of gameplay on the normal difficulty, plus some cool bonuses and optional hidden ending for the hardcore looters.

For this price, it's definitely a good buy, even if you're not particularly interested in rhythm games in the first place (that's my case, and I still really enjoyed Before the Echo).

The Rhythm Action RPG I've Always Needed\n\nI expected to find exemplary RPG gameplay on top of a familiar Bemani style of gaming.  What I didn't expect was that I'd be thrown into an awesome story with amazing voice acting, scripting, and art.  This far exceeds the bottom-line definition of DDR RPG.""
Sometimes I hate you sometimes I love you....can't make my mind when playing  this awsome and frustrating game è_é

Extremely well crafted game. Love the beat/music dance-pad like game mechanic mixed with RPG elements led by a young college-kid protagonist and female narrator who don't take the game to seriously. The voice acting sounds great (the aforementioned two are supposed to be 24 years olds in the game), and I like the way they portray the characters' idiosyncrasies. The humor is amusing.

Works great with a 360 controller. 60 fps and decent 1080p screen scaling to boot!

I'm 1/7th through the game and I would definitely recommend this to people who don't mind feeling a little pressure as they swich frantically between Mana, Spell casting, and defensive panels, each of which the player must deal with in DDR 4-way-arrow dance-style gameplay.

Recommended. I give it a 4/5.

I absolutely loved this! I loved the music which never got boring and tiresome when I was grinding for those rare items. I never had an issue with the crafting, I thought it was pretty inventive becasue it gets the player to make decisions on the items they absolutely need and then to be prepared for the crafting. I thought that the battle system was INSANE! The amount of thought and timing that goes into each battle is awesome.\nNow, my few issues were that A. It was too short and B. Some of the drop rates were a little too out there to benefit from. I mean sure there is THAT item, but it wasn't worth it and it was too much of a spike at the point when I got it (just before the final boss fight for the 6th time because SO ANNOYING)\nAll in all 9/10, you guys did AMAZING

Loving this game!  It's like Puzzle Quest and DDR got baked into a delious cake!  The tunes are memorable with some of my favorite indie artist supplying the beats for each battle.\n\n<3!

Before the Echo is like this weird Rhythm game and rpg rolled into one. You play the game by matching Arrows in three different fields. Defense blocks attacks, There's an attack field where you need to hit all the arrows to cast spells. Then there is the mana pool where you replenish your mana for more spells. The thing is you queue your spells up on your own. So you have to either take a few hits while you get a spell off on the enemy or maybe you'll find that gap in the enemy's attack pattern. Besides that the game has a ton of other rpg elements like monster drops, item synthesis, equipment, learning new spells and more.

I also enjoy the voice acting and all the snarky sarasm that goes on between the guy you play and Naia the girl over the intercom. I was really laughing at the first boss encounter poor old percival was offended by my words. Then again he was asking for it.

I say pick this up if you like rhythm games and want a splash of rpg stuff to go with it.
It's a fun game, but I think it was a big mistake to make the item crafting cost XP.\nPlaying the same songs over and over to grind for XP really isn't that fun.

Great music, good voice acting -- especially for an indie venture -- and a very nicely written story. The story is intriguing, especially later into the game, and the characters are hilarious. Dialogue is snarky and well-written, and had me laughing a lot. In my opinion, the only thing truly lacking was the gameplay, which was a little weak. I only played on medium, and it was challenging by the end of the game, but the content was repetitive.This isn't so much a problem of difficulty, but more a byproduct of the game's small pool of resources compared to many other rhythm games.\n\nAll in all, as a cheap-♥♥♥ game it's a nice buy. It makes for an especially nice deal during Steam Sales and the like.

Definitely one of the most charming games I have played, and perhaps the best $5 I can ever think of spending.  Sequence is a Rhythm-Based RPG: you fight enemies by managing three different screens where directions fall down a la Dance Dance Revolution.  It is incredibly fun with a great learning curve (this being my first game of this genre).
The game really shines in its story and humor.  Every line of dialogue is voice acted, and the jokes are tremendous.

Think of it as a favor to yourself, buying this one.

Considering that this is a blend of rhythm games and RPGs, my two favorite genres, I don't know why it didn't catch my eye on day one. The general gameplay involves switching between three play fields - one to gain mana to cast spells, one to actually use the spells, and one to defend against enemy attacks. It's the kind of concept that must be played to get a good idea of, but let me tell you, it's great. Most of the gameplay music is by Ronald Jenkees, who I now know to be a fantastic artist. While the ending is a bit lackluster on all accounts - a tad 'what the heck?', a bit of open-endedness, even on the secret ending, and a special achievement that might or might not really bug you (I was fine with it, and rather liked it) - Sequence/Before The Echo is an indie game that you need to buy right this second. Just be ready for tons of horrible puns.

Had this game recommended to me as a good music game hybrid, and was pleasantly surprised.  I'm not usually an RPG fan, but this game is enjoyable so far and there's no question that I'll see it through to the end.

As a long-time DDR/stepmania player, I stepped quite easily into hard mode.  The charts themselves are still pretty easy for me, and I can easily get 100% while unlocking spells.  However, during regular gameplay, coordinating switching between panes with hitting notes is a new and interesting challenge.

The biggest downside so far is the lack of content.  The soundtrack, while well-made, is extremely limited, and you'll end up hearing the same handful of songs over and over (so far maybe a half dozen songs in the first 4/7 floors of the tower, compared to dozens/hundreds in your average true rhythm game).  That coupled with the fact that I'm better than halfway through the game in under 4 hours suggests that this game won't have replay value.

Other thoughts:
- The art is somewhat low-res (720p?) and you can't change resolutions.  You can choose full screen or windowed though.  Not something I notice during gameplay, but nowadays I'd expect full HD (or preferably vector) art.
- So far I've only gotten one defensive spell and it's not that powerful.  There's a huge emphasis on attack-heavily-and-occasionally-heal with not much in the way of actually defending.  Some battles you can coast through without using the defense pane much at all, so it's not equally balanced throughout.
- A lot of the items/spells seem ignorable in general, unless you're a compulsive completionist like I am.
- Each floor of the tower has 3 different enemy battles (each with 3 different item drops), plus a boss battle.
- It's interesting that the item drop probabilities are shown, that way you can quantify how bad your luck is when grinding.  Sure, I got the 35% item in 3 of my last 4 battles, but I only got one of the 85% item that I need three of.  Haha.
- The boss battles don't seem to be replayable, but they do unlock new songs when you complete them that will be used in the higher levels of battle.
- Most people complaining about the name change (from Sequence") have no idea how trademark law works
date: or why companies are obligated to protect their trademarks.\n\nOverall
recommended: this game is well worth that 99c sale price
hoursPlayed: but it seems like something I'll play through once and then forget about.  I absolutely love the concept
voteText: but it needs more content for sure."

Definitely an awesome game for anyone that enjoys step mania, DDR, and possibly even rhythm and music games in general.  However, if you find Step Mania or DDR challenging or frustrating, this game is likely going to be too hard for you.  It forces you to not only hit arrow keys in time with the music in the same fashion, but adds even more layers of difficulty.  There are no color codes on the arrows themselves to tell you what beat the note is on.  So you have to go purely on listening to the music, and sometimes the arrows are just on really awkward notes or tones of the song, like a series of 16th notes where only a few of them have arrows on them.  Tack on that you are watching three sets of arrows at once instead of only 1, having to swap fields of arrows to be hitting, and apply strategic thinking to when to cast spells and what to cast SIMULTANEOUSLY and you need to be so good at something like Stepmania that you don't even have to think about the arrows.  You have to be able to do them almost completely subconsciously to keep up with this game (At least at the Hard difficulty level)  If you're that good, this game will knock your socks off.  It's incredibly fun.

The only real downsides to it come from sheer lack of variety.  The game has RPG mechanics for sure, and that includes trying to collect items with a % drop rate.  Meaning if you get unlucky (And you WILL get unlucky) you may be grinding the same exact monster for half an hour.  Which means the same damn song for half an hour straight.  What is worse, each monster does not have it's own song.  Some repeat.  This can get seriously old.

For 5$, this game is awesome.  Something I've never seen before and very well put together.  And at that price, the lack of variety is understandable.  Personally, I'd love to see a sequel, and would be happy to pay four times as much if they just make sure to really crank up the variety so the game isn't such an awful feeling grind at times.  The foundations of this game are rock solid.  It just needs a few more coats of paint.
